Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2011 07:57AM TexasKaren wrote: Cancer survivors, esp Stage IV living with mets, tend to change our entire viewpoint on life and living, I've found over the past 4 years. We come to accept the things we can not change.  We take every single blessed moment to heart, and appreciate all the little things that we never considered before.  Sunrises are more beautiful than we ever noticed.  The touch of our loved ones hands is more meaningful.  Our dog sitting on our lap is more comforting.  The blue of the sky is bluer. We no longer feel that we have time to be petty, judgemental, conceited, vain, or demanding.  Our attention focuses to sharing all the love we can with everyone we can for as long as we can.  We no longer are concerned about 'getting ahead', or 'having the most beautiful home', or even with how much we can shop and buy our clothes and shoes.  Suddenly, all the wordly things drop away, and we are left with a deeper understanding of who we are as a person, our true selves, and how strong, resilient and special we each are.  I love myself more today than I ever have, and in loving myself, I am able to love those around me more also. I feel for those of you with young children; but don't ever think that you are doing them an injustice or taking something away from their childhoods by having cancer and going through this... they are learning from you every day.  They see your strength, your courage, your willingness to battle through FOR THEM, and it will shape them for the rest of their lives, no matter what your outcome is.   Live each day to the fullest.....and always count your blessings; as much as we think we are miserable in our condition, there are always those who are far worse off somewhere in the world!! Off my soapbox now....

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2008 07:04PM TexasKaren wrote: I had my consult with my Rad Onc today too.  Start with the 'practice' session on 3/31, and then 25 treatments (5 weeks) with 8 additional boosters to the nodes because I had 8/14 positive nodes.  My Rad Onc is a lovey Indian lady doc and the techs are very nice and friendly too.  I was told basically the same as Nanstoys; basically just use common sense about being careful of your skin and not irritating it with anything.  My main gripe will be that I can't do my usual spring yardwork...sun is too hot here in Texas.... unless I cover up from neck to wrists.  That's no fun... LOL   I love what someone said about "braiding" their armpits!    To those of you feeling depressed; get some help.  Great anti-depressant medications are available, and they aren't forever; they can help you get over and through the 'bad times' and they certainly help make life more bearable.  If one brand doesn't make you feel better or has weird side effects, ask to change to another.  The statistics for cancer patients (all types/sexes) suffering depression are 70-75%.  Go figure....your whole life has been turned upside down!!  For those who are able, exercise and meditation are wonderful for beating the blues too.

Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2011 09:10AM TexasKaren wrote: I had a friend, who is a NURSE even (should know better) I haven't seen in awhile say to me after I told her my cancer came back as MBC, "Oh well, a couple more chemos and you'll be good as new".  Sheesh. I used to say "survivor"... because that's what everyone says, but now I just tell them, No, I'm not a survivor.... a survivor is one who makes it.  I am living with cancer and living the best I can every day.   That kind of stops them in their tracks. I hope all of you will post the MSBC information on your facebooks, myspace, etc, whatever on October 13... Metasatic Breast Cancer Day.   If you don't know... go to the Metastatic Breast Cancer Network site and get the 13 Facts sheet (link below).  I've sent that to my local newspapers, but I doubt they'll publish it.  People don't want that kind of 'news'. http://www.mbcn.org/developing-awareness/category/13-things-everyone-should-know-about-metastatic-breast-cancer/

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2012 11:11PM TexasKaren wrote: Ok girls..  The Halaven quit after 3 cycles.  BUMMER.  I was hoping for more, but that seems to be the usual with me.  My longest response was the Avastin/Abraxane which lasted almost 6 months.  THE GOOD NEWS is that my bone scan looks good, very tiny progression in one hip; rest is stable.  So, that made me feel better.  My 'marker' for chemo's working are the lymphatic skin mets on my chest, and this week (my chemo free week after the 3rd cycle) I popped up with them on my BACK now and under my left arm in addition to the ones on my chest coming back.  BUT, this is all superficial and not in any organs, etc, Praise God!  I have nodes in my left eye too; will see about doing orbital radiation (I didn't think they could radiate the eye, but they block the eyeball itself and just radiate the masses inside the boney orbital area.)  Doc is trying to find Doxil, but it's one of the ones that is EXTREMELY hard to get now. I won't leave you.... I'll probably get on a Doxil board to see what's up (If I can get it!) but I'll check in with all of you.  You are all special ladies, as is everyone on these BC.org boards !! If I can't get Doxil, will do Carboplatin and some other name I never heard of... LOL  Doc really wants the Doxil.  I was 3 years out after treatment with Adriamycin/Cytoxan... he feels that Doxil, which is a form of Adriamycin, but different, will maybe hit it. Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2012 02:06PM TexasKaren wrote: Penny:  You keep me in stitches.... I have lots of stuff growing in my fish tank, since I haven't cleaned it in about 6 mos, but the fish don't seem to mind, but I don't think sponges are there yet. Donese:  It' VERY important, imperative! that you schedule some YOU time... find someone else to take the load for the day and go fishing, or drive in the hill country, go golfing, whatever you enjoy.  Robin will totally understand.  You will burn out fast if you "try to do it all".  You are not superman, neither are we super women, although we like to think we are (LOL). Exercise is important too, but don't know if you can work that into your busy schedule! All: I read a very inspiring book by Ken Wilber, "Grace and Grit", about his wife's journey through cancer.  He was the 'ultimate' caregiver, even giving up his own career, and there was a time when he became a closet alcholic and totally resentful for her and all of it... and she had unknowinghly become totally codependent on him also; it was a bad time for both, but they confronted it and realized that they had to find balance, and worked it out.  I have friends who are caregivers for their parents with Alzheimers, and I often see the same 'resentment' building.  Don't allow that to happen.  We, the cancer patient, don't want any of our loved ones to harm themselves (mentally, physically or spiritually) in their care of us.  There are too many other resources out there; just have to ask for help and find it.

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2011 11:22AM TexasKaren wrote: My onc said that, (1) after rads, (2) on Xgeva or Zometa, (3) adequate calcium intake, some LIGHT weight bearing (no more than 5#-8# weights) excercise is good.  Cancer is very muscle-wasting (as if we didn't notice), and he recommended to keep muscle mass going, to help strengthen the bones, and more importantly, the ligaments/muscles around bones (for lifting, carrying things, etc), to get lots of protein (muscle milk is good!) and excercise cautiously... not body build, but maintaining muscle mass.   I'm not sure it's working, but I'm trying  :) I love you horsey people out there!  But I would be afraid to ride now.... I have never been a 'fragile' person at all, but lately, even stepping off of curbs or high steps poses me into a cautionary mode after I saw my spine MRI and shoulder.   Good news:  I finally was made to stop carrying a large, heavy handbag (which seems to be the trend now!)... I now have a small, light handbag, and I leave all my necessary crap at home.  (I miss it though!)

Posts.Title: How do you deal with all the questions? Canchaser TexasKaren

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2011 06:45AM TexasKaren wrote: You must find support at this time... neighbors, family, friends, and your fiance.  Now is the time to call to action for help with your mom and with your own self.  Son who is unemployed needs to be part of the team for you and your mom (I know about unemployed sons..!).  Talk to your employer... if you can still work sufficiently to fulfill your obligations, but cut back on hours, etc, if they are willing to work with you, do it.  If not, SSI disability is a sure thing for you.  Fitztwins is right: Find out about any insurance policy with accelerated benefits.... my policies let me take 50% with doctor opinion on less than 1 year to live and then the rest upon death (it's not a death sentence, it's only a physicians' opinon, and the insurance company usually doesn't fight it when you are Stage IV).   Also, consult your cancer care center for other resources.  There is a national organization that will do free housecleaning for you (unfortunately, not available to me here in the backwaters of west Texas), and other agencies that can help.  You can get your phone bill reduced (AT&T) for disability, and check with your electric provider also for help. I am so sorry you are going through this, but you beat liver and lung mets, and you will beat brain mets too!!!!  Praying for you !!  Take care of #1 first.... and get help for the rest.
Posts.Title: Brain mets diagnosis carpediemocc Lena

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2011 07:32PM TexasKaren wrote: The new hair is colorless (grey/white/silver) because the keratin (which contains the pigment cells) doesn't come back for a few months after the hair grows back.  Of course, my hair was grey to begin with, but friends hair came in 'grey' and went back to natural color around 4-6 months out.  I had to wait, but then couldn't wait to color it again !! Since hair and skin cells are some of the most rapidly reproducing, (and therefore, the normal ones that become collateral damage to chemotherapy drugs which are targeting rapidly growing cells in the body), your hair all over your body will come back faster/more again, legs, underarms, etc.  But, after a while, it will settle back to normal.  I still have some chiny chin chin hairs that I have to take care of with tweezers... but, maybe because I'll be 60 this year too !

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2011 10:02AM - edited Sep 2, 2011 10:02AM by TexasKaren I find this to be true too, and most of it is that people do not understand the different faces of breast cancer.  Most think you get your breast cut off and do chemo and you're cured.  There is a total lack of education out there. I have taken the opposite tact... I use my MBC as a tool to educate people.  I do not dwell on the absolute negatives when I talk about it (that my chances are 1 in 2 that I will not live past 2 years as I have a very aggressive beast), but I take that line that I will be forever on some form of treatment from now on, to CONTROL the disease, there is no cure.  I also do not try to dump all my symptoms and side effects on people, but just tell them that chemo can cause some problems, but that I am handling them the best I can and I am taking every day as a gift and living in a state of joy to be here.  I also use humor to lessen their discomfort (My hair doesn't know if it's falling in our out right now, but it's only hair... most men don't have any either).  I post my 'chemo days' on FB and laugh about how it's time to go sit and get poisoned and that no one knows the fun I'm having sitting in a chair for 4 hours, etc.  My friends have responded with great enthusiasm and support and always give me a 'go girl!" back. You should see the responses I get from being honest with people..... they go from being politely indifferent (oh how are you doing dear?) or "clueless" to suddenly seeing my life as I do... a gift that I am handling in my own way.  Their concern and support then becomes much more real and then, if I do need some sort of support from them, even if it's just to ask for their prayers, it becomes something they want to do and not just "lip service" to someone with a disease they don't understand.  The old saying is true.... just walk a mile in my shoes. BUT, there are also people who just don't get it and are always a pain to be around... LOL.  Face it, you don't need any negativity in your life; avoid them. If you have just been dx'd Stage 4, you may need some time to get used to your own feelings and fears too, so don't feel bad about hiding out for awhile... but do know that there are a lot of really caring people out there who will make you feel better by being part of your life and don't become a recluse.  Look at all of us here in this wonderful community !!!  We are here for you at any time you need to talk or vent!  We are all sisters in this fight.

Posts.Title: How do you deal with all the questions? Canchaser TexasKaren

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2011 05:19PM TexasKaren wrote: Reesie is right.... for those of us who had primary dx and lumpectomy, etc, we had chemo and rads.  When recurrence occurs, it is not to the primary site (breast) but to the bones.  If not too large/damaging lesions, chemo is first line, but if large lesions destroying bone, or if painful, radiation to those areas they can do it on is great.   I've had rads to lower spine, upper spine, and shoulder.  It has halted the bone destruction and given me great pain relief. If this was your primary dx and at stage IV, I would do all that I could to fight the beast.... radiation to breast included.
Posts.Title: Confused about stage iv radiation DivineMrsM DivineMrsM

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2011 10:03AM TexasKaren wrote: I'm fixing to lose my hair for the second time in three years, and to me, it's no big deal.  I have three wigs from my first time in 07', but they are so hot and itchy!  I just decided to 'go with it", and I was amazed when I went "au naturel" the first time at the response I got from caring, compassionate people.  They didn't gawk and stare, but many came up to me and wanted me to know that they lost a loved one to cancer too, and that they were pulling (and praying) for me.  It was so humbling and sweet.  My granddaughters love it because I look like their daddy (my son, who is bald...)  I like to buy some fun 'temporary tattoos' and put them on my little bald head (a little butterfly on the back of the head, or a little dragon crawling up one side) and people love it.  Of course, it's hotter than hades in Texas now, so bald is cool and 'in'.  Just have to wear lots of sunscreen !    When it started growing back in and I looked like a fuzzy duckling, it was strange, but so soft and silver, I didn't mind.  I did wait 6 months before coloring it back to my 'redhead' status again, because my hairdresser advised that the new cortical of the hair could become damaged from the chemicals, even the gentle ones.  I see many around me at my cancer center and you know what?  We are all very beautiful women, hair or no hair or any stage in between.  I see shining eyes and hearts and souls full of life... I don't see bald or fuzzy. If you haven't listened to it in awhile, remember India Arie's song.."I Am Not My Hair"  (with lyrics) http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Mop9csVOF6E Very uplifting for those "bad hair" days !!!

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2007 01:55PM TexasKaren wrote: Welcome Parsnip!   Sorry about your lung complication!  Hope it's all resolved and your not having any lingering effects.  Ask your oncologist about ice chips before the adriamycin.  My onc team gives me a big glass of ice chips and I literally freeze my mouth off before and during the adriamycin infusion.  I haven't had a mouth sore yet.  It reduces the blood flow to those tissues, so the A doesn't have a chance to flow there.   Of course, get a couple of blankets ready; it makes you cold all over eating all that ice! Sounds like we're on the same protocol.  I have two more doses of A/C and then 4 of T/C and then radiation after the new year. Hair is individual, but usually somewhere around day 14.  Mine started at day 12, but now it's day 20 (post chemo#2 5 days) and it's down to little bits of tufts.  I expect it will finish up by the end of this weekend, or if there are still little stragglers, I'll go get a shave by my hairdresser.  I still go 'pluck' my head a couple times a day to hurry it along, and wear a little sleep cap to keep it from falling out all over the place.  I can't wait for it to finish!!  My eyebrows and arm hair and stuff are still there.... it may be chemo#3 before I lose them.  Hang in there... yes, I am having temperature control issues too.  I'm either freezing or hot flushing.  No happy medium. Lori and decided we don't smell... our smellers just aren't working right and we just smell to ourselves.  So, tell yourself that you are a rose and don't worry about it!

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2008 02:57AM TexasKaren wrote: Theresa:   You know a lot about this from being a nurse, but I know you haven't gone through it yourself.  Everyone is different, but my experience was: The A/C wasn't extremely bad itself (just the loss of hair and the taste/food/tummy issues), but the thing that I think everyone agrees with is that the neulasta is what kicked our butts.  But, we understand it's importance.  I basically felt pretty good (wired on steroids for two days) until the neulasta, then was a total washout-hurtbeyondbelief-couch potatoe for two more days... then by the 5th-6th day, things got relatively back to normal and I was ok (except for the food/taste issues) until the next treatment.  Be prepared to find food that you can eat, even if you have to live on the same stuff for 8 weeks (mine was only the following: applesauce, yogurt, puddings, chicken soup, rice, bananas) and tell your doc if you need some protonix or something for the acid reflux.  I NEVER had any tummy issues (stomach of iron!) until chemo.  As as nurse you know, DRINK DRINK DRINK.  I could feel when I needed to increase my drinking because my digestive symptoms got worse.  It should be FLUSH FLUSH FLUSH !  Get agressive with the constipation too.  Phillips caps have become my lil' friends... I started the taxotere and thought that it was a breeze, but it too is becoming cumulative.  BUT, other than the increasing tiredness and some redeveloping taste/food issues, it's still not as rough as the A/C was, but the A/C was only bad for the first 5-6 days for me (I still think the neulasta is what makes the A/C suck, but my blood counts were above normal, so it works!).  Hey, I still played with my rock n roll band every weekend!!  You'll learn to adjust your schedule to fit your treatment schedule and the effects. You can do this fine!! And you have great support.   One thing I've discovered about myself.  I'm more flexible than I thought... I can do things I never thought I could do, and I can handle more than I ever thought I could handle.  Come to think about it, I'm doing pretty good at 55, and I'm going to do even better at 56!  The old saying is true:  "I'm not getting older, I'm getting BETTER"!

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2008 11:37AM TexasKaren wrote: I know.... giving up the sugar thing is hard.  I've not eaten a lot of refined sugar in a couple of years, but I've been doing Nutrasweet for years.  Now I find out that it is one of the worst things to do! I've gotten myself down to 1 Diet Dr. Pepper every other day.  I'm trying to cut down on the coffee too... one a day at the most.  We don't eat a lot of sweets anyway, I've been doing the "no carb" thing for 3 years, so desserts/cakes/donuts, etc aren't a problem. The pork/bacon will be hard too, but turkey bacon/sausage isn't bad if you cook it right.  For my life and the life of my DH, I can do this!  I have found Stevia in the market now, and it's ok; it's VERY sweet, so you have to go carefully with it! YES, stating positive thoughts out loud is important!  All of the books and 'gurus' on the subject from Joel Osterman to Dyanetics(sp) tell us that what we speak can become manifested.  I also believe strongly and try to practice NEVER saying my negative thoughts out loud.  It's very hard... we all want to gripe and moan and groan, but negativity breeds negativity.  You ever have any friends who absolutely never had anything positive to say?  I had one, and I had to leave the friendship because her negativity about everything was a total energy drain on me and I was becoming ill from the relationship.  As positive and affirming I could be, I couldn't change her negative outlook on life and everything in the world. Since cancer hit me, I have become conscientiously aware now of those in need around me.  It's a hightened sense of awareness where before cancer, I went along my merry "I'm ok, so you must be ok" way.  I try to 'pay back and pay forward' whenever I can, that's why I got the band and all our musician friends to do the benefit.  And you know what?  Now they are all talking about doing another one!!  Cheryl:  I LOVE the idea of the Valentine tree... but don't forget Shamrocks for St. Paddy's Day ! ! !

Sisters:  Hey, did you read the news about Aspirin and cancer?  Seems like that good ol' little white pill is helpful in cancer prevention AND treatment.  I've continued to take my low-dose (81 mg) aspirin throughout treatment, except on the days of chemo or lab because it made me bleed a little more.  They are saying that studies in mice prove that it helps the chemo fight the cancer better, and also that aspirin keeps the cancer cells from 'hiding' in the body better for prevention.  They did studies the last couple of years that showed that it helped to prevent colon cancer, and of course, we all know the benefits on the heart and cardiovascular system.  SO ladies, if you can tolerate aspirin ok (no allergies or bleeding ulcers, etc) start taking the little boogers!  Link to article: http://news.yahoo.com/s/nm/20080307/hl_nm/cancer_aspirin_dc_1 This also goes along with what I read in that book by Philip Quillen and 'beating cancer with nutrition'. I think you'll find it very nice to hear all the compliments!  In fact, this weekend I was at a huge formal black tie dinner.  I wore my black cocktail dress and went 'natural' and most there didn't even know or guess that I was battling cancer!!  Short hair is becoming very "in" now, and all I got was compliments on my new look!!  My problem is not the short hair, which I'm actually kind of digging, but the color... it's SO GREY!!!  But, again, all I'm getting is compliments, so I have to believe that not everyone is telling me lies!!

Posts.Content: May 8, 2008 11:57AM TexasKaren wrote: Ulla sweetie:   I am very glad that the 'cat is out of the bag'.... you need to be open with your family; even though they are far away from you, their prayers and their love will shine through to you and uplift you.  Yes, they will worry, but, that's what love and families are for.   And I know that they will be so proud of you for coming through this so well and so strong!  I'm sorry that it all happened on a bad day though!  We can't always time things the way we would want them. I don't know what to tell you about the medications; I do know several ladies here on Tamoxifen or on Herceptin for the next few years, and they are doing fine.  I'm sorry your doctor was a jerk... sometimes they just are; sometimes they are so overwhelmed with patients they can't possibly keep us all straight or remember us.  After working with Ob/Gyn's for 30 years, I know!    Talk to your other doc next week, and go slow... the girls are right, you have the 'biggest' part of your treatment over now (chemo and rads) and now you can tackle the 'maintenance' program and see what will work for you.  The goal is to have balance... to LIVE LONG AND LIVE WELL!!!

Posts.Content: May 16, 2008 10:10AM TexasKaren wrote: Cheryl:  I can't believe that!!  You should also contact the hospital/clinic director and let them know.  Bad feedback from patients is terribly 'moving' to the people at the top...it gets them fired up!   I am fortunate here; Hendrick Hospital is one of the top 10 places in America to work (2nd year in a row, Gallup Great Places in America to Work), and their attitude is terrific.  They work with you every way they can.    MY LAST RAD WAS TODAY!   I'm so glad I don't have to drive back and forth every day.... except.... our band is playing in Abilene this weekend, so I'll be over there tomorrow... and Saturday... and then I have my onc appt on Tuesday.   Shoot... I guess I'm still driving every day, huh?!?!?!   I loved what Deb said about two different worlds before and after...!! Question; other than teeth problems, has anyone else noticed any arthritis type symptoms?  I've never even had a hint of arthritis, but since I finished Taxotere, both my knees and one wrist are KILLING me every day!!  I can't wait to ask my onc about it.  My DH has arthritis so I know it's what it is; Aleve helps, but boy, it's like overnight my body aged about 20 years.   sucks..... I know.. I'm whining... Sorry.

Posts.Content: May 22, 2008 01:45PM TexasKaren wrote: Yes!  I think we are all doing better, getting back to 'normal' (sort of) and trying to catch up on all the stuff we've let slide for the past few months.  I'm swamped in my office as I was only working "part time" while going for radiation every day.  And I'm trying to get some yard work done, but it got real hot fast and I'm not up to the heat yet.  I did spray bug spray all over the yard this morning.  I started back to the Fitness Center again, and went this morning and did my mile, my crunches, etc.  I'll feel it tomorrow!!!  I'm trying hard to get my 'mo-jo' back.  I just don't have any energy or endurance anymore, but I'm praying I can fix that too in the coming weeks! Karen and Cheryl:  I'm starting to really feel good about my silly hair (it still looks strange to me in the mirror though).  I get the strangest, nicest compliments from total strangers, and to me it appears that they don't even realize that I've had chemo; they just think it's a neat new short hair cut!  One lady in the grocery store just kept saying how nice it was to look so good in short hair and how she wished she could wear short hair, etc.  When the band plays I get lots of compliments too from strangers...course, they just think I'm some punk rocker.  LOL  One girl said I looked like Jamie Lee Curtis... !  I've even stopped putting the darker color stuff on it and just go natural now.  I can't stop running my hands through it.  I've never had curly hair, and it feels so funny and fluffy!  I saw my onc yesterday and won't go back for 3 months, but then it will be time for some follow up scans.  My surgical scar on the boob where the last booster rads were given is itching like a booger; she said it would take a week or more to reach the peak of the effects of treatment and then it would start to go away.  My back and shoulder area is almost all healed now, no peeling or red.  Cheryl:  When do you get your walking cast off and can get walking again?  I know you will be so glad!  Yes, gas is bad...!  And I'm in Texas!  We've got over $800 on our gas cards now because of my radiation.  I'm waiting for our "incentive" check from Uncle Sam ... !!

LOL   The back is very curly, but I can't take a pic of that myself.  Linda:  It's fun getting a new wardrobe!  I hope you are happy with the new ones!  I'm trying to start wearing a bra again (lord knows I need the support...gravity is taking over!) but it's still tender over the radiation area.  Maybe another week... "

Posts.Content: May 27, 2008 11:38AM TexasKaren wrote: Lori:  That's a tough one....  I think I have the opposite problem.  My DH goes out of his way to show me that both sides are still the same to him...I'm the one who doesn't want him necessarily touching or playing with the 'bad boob'.  (For one reason, half of it is 'dead' to the touch after the surgery...can't feel much).  BUT, it occured to me just the other night after reading your post and thinking about it that I think I believed that he'd catch the cancer by touching it!!  Isn't that ridiculous!  But, all of a sudden, that's what I knew I was thinking all this time!!  How stupid.  I'm a nitwit.  LOL  It's amazing what we think we're thinking when deep down in our subconscience we're thinking something else. My opinion (for my 2 cents), if you two love each other, then you need to have an honest discussion about it, and not let your ego/feelings get in the way.  You have to understand that even if he does love you unconditionally, there still may be some feelings of uncomfortableness over your scars, etc.  Some things just bother people, like surgeries and disfigurations, and it takes awhile to 'get used' to them.   I had an uncle with throat cancer and he had a tracheotomy and voice tube... I don't think I ever became comfortable around him, it always bothered me a great deal to look at that (I was younger though, it probably wouldn't bother me now as much). And as far as touching, he may just be afraid of hurting you or something by touching you there!   Just talk..... be open and honest.

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2008 01:11PM TexasKaren wrote: HAPPY BIRTHDAY LINDA!!!   It's a wonderful birthday when you can look back over the last year and see how much you've gone through, how much you've endured, and how strong and resilient you've become!!  Makes you feel like aging is not the 'demon' you always thought it was!  I'm not nearly as bothered by aging now as I was before bc!!  Now, I actually look forward to being 92 someday!  And you are right... new boobs are a great present!!  Today was the National Cancer Survivors Day and I gave my little speech in between two others.  It was a wonderful event, there were around 150 people there, and I was even interviewed for TV (but on a channel we don't get here in Sweetwater! LOL)  My DH played his guitar and there were lots of speeches and the oncology nurses did a little song and dance number that was just precious (to "Ain't No Mountain High Enough")!  Everyone got a packet with a butterfly in it, and we released them all at the same time and they fluttered around and landed on us and fluttered off again.  It was lovely (even at 100 degrees!)
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2008 04:34AM TexasKaren wrote: Linda:  That's so FUNNY and TRUE!!!   I've never seen how women can think those 'cantelopes under the skin' boobs are attractive!  Also, makes you feel good to know that your surgeon really knew his stuff, too!!  Wear those puppies proudly! I'm exhausted today... feeling my age.  Played TWO benefits yesterday (why do we keep doing this to ourselves??!)... but we had a good time.  Raised over $3500 for two local volunteer fire departments and over $6,000 for medical expenses for two kids hurt in a very bad motorcycle accident.  One lost his right arm and leg in it.  SO.... I'm tired, but satisfied.   My DH and I had a very funny thought together last night.  Most of the people who come to the club we play at most of the time (Strawberry's... a great pool hall/dance/bar) are old hippie bikers, and most are our age (50's).  They love to dance to the old classic rock and roll.  We had this vision of us playing still in another 15-20 years, circa 2020... and all of them out there in their walkers and canes, still boogying!!  Ain't that a great thought! Have any of you seen video's or heard of Young@Heart?  Go to www.YouTube.com  and put that in the search box.  They are a bunch of 70-80 year olds who are performing, making videos, playing concerts, and they are so cool... I want to be just like them when I grow up! I'm going to go take some more ibuprophen and try to go clean the hot tub... storm blew the lid off and dumped a bunch of stuff in it.  I hate that chore.  But, I can't soak my tired bones in it until it's cleaned up!  LOL!    HUGS sisters!

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2008 10:38AM TexasKaren wrote: LORI!  Wow... you're as curly as I am !!  I think you look great !!  Yes, I still think it's a riot too... I can't tell who I'm looking at in the mirror, and people don't recognize me at all.    I'm not going to cut it but I think I need it shaped... the top is growing faster than the sides and it's starting to look 'lopsided'.  I haven't colored it either; people keep telling me not to, but I just can't get used to the grey/silver.  Karen looks great too, and Cheryl, and Ulla, and... ALL of us !!! It's great to be back to "normal", but I can't believe how far I let things go during the 8 months of treatment... my yard...my house.... my job... etc etc.  Did I just get really lazy???  Now I'm paying for it !!!  And for some reason, some of the stuff just doesn't seem as important anymore and I have trouble 'psyching myself up' to get it done... but it has to be done!!!  Anyone else feeling like this? Do you all know about the Susan Komen Foundation 3-day walks??  60 miles in 3 days!!!  I have a cousin in Dallas doing it with her team in November.  I'd love to get a team together for next year for Dallas, but I seriously don't know anyone out here who would do it with me, and I'm not sure I could do it (15-22 miles a day for 3 days!).... I have chronic plantar fascitis in my foot, and it hurts to just do the walking I'm doing to try to keep fit, let along go 60 miles!!  But, I'm supporting her and her team.  She's already raised $3,800 and is shooting for $5,000.  If you're not familiar with the event, go to www.the3day.org  .... maybe you can find a team to support too from your area or your state.  Go to the "donate now" and you can look up names or cities of teams. Cheryl:  How's the ankle doing???     Also, my friend who had surgery and was afraid it was ovarian cancer came out negative... severe endometriosis (with no symptoms! very rare!) and leiomyoma in her uterus...they went ahead and did hysterectomy; she never wanted children and this will keep her from developing further problems.  So, big relief!  Thanks for your prayers.

Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2008 06:41AM TexasKaren wrote: Cheryl:  I feel for you honey!! I have been fortunate with menopause: I have the flashes and night sweats, but I don't get the insomnia and mood swings.  But my best friend had a terrible time.  She tried lots of the over the counter stuff.  Tylenol pm works somewhat most of the time.  Exercise and meditation helps.  And yes, the lack of sleep makes anyone irritable!!  Since we can't take estrogens anymore, the best treatment for the side effects is out.  One of my best 'fixes' is I keep a neck pillow (one of the U-shaped things) in the refrigerator and when a "big one" hits, I grab it; seems to cut the flash right off with some deep breathing too.  Now, of course, putting that pillow on everytime isn't possible when you're running errands downtown, etc., but it sure helps around the house.  I have a little battery powered fan in my purse... a personal fan.  LOL  My friends all ask to borrow it when were out!!!  And keep in mind... like everything in life, this too shall pass... two or three years from now you won't have them anymore !! I've tried everything with my plantar fascitis...massive ibuprophen therapy (12-16 a day x several weeks) is the only thing that works and yes, I wear special orthotics in all my shoes and never go barefoot (I miss that!).  Doc says if it doesn't get better, he'll cut the nerve, but then that can also lead to problems I don't want.  I'm glad I'm not the only one who really hasn't 'returned to normal!".  LOL  You know what though?  I don't really care.  I would rather get up and sit outside and watch my hummingbirds fight and drink my one cup of coffee and feel the sun on my face than go back to jumping out of bed, picking up the house, vacumming, etc.   The simple pleasures are so much more enjoyable now!  I'd love to spend a weekend at your Pocono house, Kara ! !   The pictures were so beautiful I saw.

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2008 10:35PM TexasKaren wrote: Deb:  Love the hair; you look gorgeous!!  Sorry that you have to do the 'venting'... but, that's why you got Sista's in the Hood, honey!  Sometimes it's better and easier to voice your problems to these internet friends than your family and friends; we can be more objective I think, and also many of us have shared the same things in our lives.   Time to sit hubby down and ask him what is driving him to drink more.... it may just be a stress reaction to all his work and all that's happened that he's not aware of.  Could be he hung in there tough with you during treatment and now he's decompensating... but you need to talk to him about it.  As the ex-wife of a functional alchoholic, been there, done that.  Daughter has 'made her bed' and you are right; at this point you can't say much.  Just let her know you're always there for her and be a gracious mother in law.  Cheryl:  I'm so glad your mom is with you...!  Hopefully, maybe she'll make a decision to move closer, but at least for now you can get her taken care of properly. IKE affected a lot of my friends and the doctors I work for... I'm trying to get in touch with many of them, but no power for 3 weeks in some areas.  I've got that meeting in Mexico in two weeks, and I guess I'll have to go without reports from many of my board members.  We didn't get anything here in the west part of Texas, but I know Ike was going to dump rain up through the central states...hope you all don't get any flooding. I, too, am having my colonoscopy on Tuesday... such fun!  I'd rather clean my garage........ Speaking of.... we had a WHIMS meeting the other day and a wonderful lady came from Dallas, an artist and writer.  If any of you enjoy reading uplifting cancer books, her's is: "I'd rather do Chemo than Clean my Garage... Choosing Laughter Over Tears" (Fran Di Giacomo)... I read it and it's marvelous.  She's a PhD...Perpetually Hairless Dame.  LOL  She's been on and off chemo for 10 years...ovarian cancer, 27 surgeries to date (breast cancer 20 years ago).  She was a riot and very uplifting to hear talk.  They have her book on Amazon.com.  Her beautiful artwork is at www.frandigiacomo.com Fall is coming fast...!  Our hummingbirds are starting to migrate to Mexico, they know something we don't!  Maybe an early frost!
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2008 11:20PM TexasKaren wrote: Cheryl:  So glad the wrist is 'fixed' and she's doing better... all around!  Sorry that you're area got hit by Ike's wrath too.  Lots of my friends in Galveston and Houston are still without power and not home yet.  It's going to be a huge mess for awhile. Sorry I haven't been on much... big meeting in Midland-Odessa this weekend, and then only two days to get ready for my trip to Mexico again..!  I've got so much to do and I keep forgetting things!  I'm "list making" like crazy, because I have to pack hubby off on a trip too!   Heard a great talk at my meeting this weekend on the anti-estrogen drugs and how they affect our bodies, related to menopause, etc.  My onc is not exactly correct in saying that chemo (taxotere) didn't cause my arthritis... but this expert says that the anti-estrogen compounds accelerate the aging process because of the rapid decrease of estrogens; not the natural slow decrease.  Even women going through menopause taking Premarin, etc, go slower into the 'old age' effects of declining estrogens because they are still getting them.  Makes sense to me.  I have felt 10 years older since my cancer and I can't believe the aches and pains I have now that I didn't have a year ago.  Cure?  nope... just the usual; exercise, watch diet, keep fit, etc.  Can't take estrogens anymore, so I'll just have to look at the bright side of post chemo and say; well, at least I don't have cancer right now!! Blessings to all !!!

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2008 09:37PM TexasKaren wrote: Hey gang!  Sorry I haven't been around. Had a wonderful meeting in Los Cabos and am back now, but darn!  It was SOOO HOT there, and HUMID; and there was no ocean breeze... I've never been on the coast where there wasn't a breeze.  Guess we just hit it at the wrong time.  It was miserable, but if we stayed in the meetings and went right into the pools, it was ok.  Got back to sad news; one of the guys in our band's family was in a terrible head on car accident on the highway and his 3 month old granddaughter was killed, his wife has a broken hip, ribs, and both ankles and knee, and the baby's mother has a smashed nose (not just broken, but smashed into 12 pieces!) The other two grand kids in the car are ok, and the baby's dad had severe bruising.  So, have been busy getting aid to the family and setting up benefits for them.  Poor 19 year old kid swerved to avoid hitting a deer (big problem here in TX) and lost control of his car, smashed through the median and hit them head on.  He wasn't hurt too bad, but is in terrible mental condition over the guilt of the accident.  Pray for them all.  We don't always understand the mysteries of life and death, but we are seeing a miracle in this community of people from all walks and faiths coming together to help....it's so heartwarming. My insurance company denied my colonoscopy!!!  I'm in a fight now.  I hadn't had a screening colonoscopy before and I'm 56.  I think they're just tired of paying out $$ for me.

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2008 03:18AM TexasKaren wrote: Karen!  Glad to see you are doing ok... I'm glad your mom is close to you, I know it's probably been very hard for her and she's blessed to have you by her.  Sounds like your daughter is one of the very talented 'right brain' people who's passion lies in other directions than the 'normal' world expects.  Artistic people operate on a different plane than most of us; I know because I've known some extremely talented musicians who are like your daughter.  Couldn't care less about math, reading, etc, but have amazing abilities in other areas.  Learning to balance the two sides is hard for them.  They just dont' see what's so important about that other stuff... Our Whimsapalooza II cancer support benefit was very dissappointing.  We only made about $750 which is less than last year, but the biggest disappointment to me was that only about 4 of the WHIMS members showed up, none of the doctors and only the two main nurse coordinators who stayed for 1/2 hour.  The ladies didn't even support their own event.  I'm a little disgusted with the Abilene group.  You'd have to live here to understand... Abilene is home to three of the strongest "church" colleges in Texas...and everyone is very "religious", but to the point of being very hypocritical.  I'm not knocking church or religion; I'm very spiritual myself, but the dogma that is practiced that excludes even stepping into a club (and it's the nicest club in Abilene and Abilene is non-smoking too!) for 45 mins to support your own support group is amazing to me to understand.  Even Christ ate with the lepers and the sinners....  Well, enough of my soap box.  I'll let them do their own benefit next year.... It was hours and hours of work for me and I poured a lot of my own money into it and I'll let someone else head it up next year.   Am I chewing sour grapes???? My hair is finally starting to "settle down" some, guess it's getting longer and the length is pulling the curl out of it.  I re-dyed it with some henna product today, and I like it a lot better; it's more chestnut than orange! LOL.  I'm posting a pic of our halloween party... my 'mask' man and me... LOL FALL here is beautiful... if my allergies weren't so bad I'd be outdoors all day!!

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2010 12:02AM TexasKaren wrote: Evy:   I feel for you, sugar!  You are in a time of your life that whether or not you had BC you would find yourself at odds... I went through it when my children were young, and I know several others who did also.  It's a crazy, hectic, challenging time of life and it seems like even the floor drops out of marriages, no time for each other, no time for fun or yourself, etc.  You love your kids and your home, but you wonder what you are there for? Just a cook/cleaner/taxi driver?  You wonder if you missed something, but you don't know what.  Just hang in there... take every day as it comes, and look around at your blessings.  You'll come through on the other side knowing that what you did WAS important and you certainly did matter.  AND, stop and smell the roses sometimes.  You deserve it!!

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2012 03:48PM TexasKaren wrote: I love all you ladies too... !  The ones I've met on the boards are the best mentors, life-coaches, and inspiration to me ever.  No one else, not even my DH, can compare.  We are all peas in a pod and it's so nice to know there are people to share this horrible/wonderful journey with. (I say wonderful, because cancer teaches us so much too!)  I pray for all of us daily. I especially admire and pray hard for those of you with children still at home.  My sons are almost 40 and 37, and I have two granddaughters, 5 and 3.  When people say that I'm strong, I tell them that they don't know strong until they meet some of you out there !!  I am Karen, 59 1/2, from Sweetwater, TX, married to the most wonderful man ever and with a totally spoiled (but she spoils me too), dauchsund, Skittle.  Original Stage II dx in Sept 2007, IDC, 8/14 nodes positive.  Lumpectomy, usual chemo and radiation.  Joined BCO at that time and was with a wonderful group of "October 2007 Chemo Girls".  6 of us are still in constant touch; only one of us has had a local recurrence (thank God) and I'm the only one progressed to mets which were found in Dec. 2010.  All over neck, spine, ribs, lower left jaw, right shoulder, pelvis, and now it looks like it's in my eye too (yea, I know.. WTH?!)  Skin mets too, which aren't pretty.  Have failed on Gemzar, Xeloda, Navelbine (worked 2 1/2 months), Avastin/Abraxane (worked for 6 months), and now looks like I've failed on Halaven too, after only 3 cycles.  That's 6 chemos in 14 months... that sucks lemons.  I've got a nasty ER+ (very weak), PR-/HER- agressive beast.  I may go to MD Anderson soon to see what they have for me, but I love my onc in Abilene and he's done everything he can for me; he even consults with other oncs on my behalf.   Also on Xgeva and have had rads to spine and shoulder which were awesome at stopping pain/etc. Taking it a day at a time, loving life, and knowing that God's plan is the best for me....

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2011 09:21AM TexasKaren wrote: What a nightmare for you !!  I'm praying hard for both of you, and I thank God that you were there to save his life.  He will thank you too. Our caregivers have a harder road than we do, I do believe... and they often do not have any support for themselves!!  Being the "Strong silent type" should be a clue... these people (my husband is one) keep everything bottled up inside.  We think they are strong, but they are hiding their pain, frustration, looking at a future without their loved one, everything.  I have to literally "pull" my husband out sometimes to make him talk about his feelings about what we are going through, and we're not even to the point of full caregiving yet... I'm still normally functional, cooking, cleaning, etc.  We have tough roads to face ahead I know. I know he'll get some help now, and hopefully, there is a support group for you both to be in.  He needs to "let go" and get some support for both you and himself in some way, friends, home health, etc.   Your love will survive this... I'm sure!
Posts.Title: STAGE FOUR NIGHTMARE. AussieSheila ibcmets

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2007 09:15AM TexasKaren wrote: Hi you lovely ladies of power and courage!  TexasKaren back online.  The wind storms in West Texas blew down our T-1 tower (we're out in the boonies, so that's our only internet option) and I was without internet for 4 days!  It took me awhile to read everyone's posts, and to know that overall everyone is doing good (except chickenpoxpie...hahaha, that's funny, but not)  My first week after first chemo is over, and except for being out in 'la-la land' for two days after the chemo (yea, DebKay, it's a weird trip!) and then hurting over every inch of my body the next two days after neulasta shot, by Friday I was "HUMAN" again!!  And even good enough to go to play with our band Friday night, Saturday day and Saturday night, although I sure was pooped by Sat. night.  If I have to give up 4 days out of every two weeks, then I think I can make it.  I'm starting to see hair coming out a lot in my brush, but they said that it's usually 10-14 days and certainly after the second dose of adriamycin that it happens.  I'm planning on getting a real short cut next week, and then I may/may not shave by the weekend for our Halloween bash... depends on how it's falling!  I actually am really looking forward to not shaving my legs, etc, ETC(!), for awhile!  I have bought a bunch of temporary tatoos to wear as well as some funky hats (ebay has a lot of really wild fun hats!)  Karen, Eva, Ulla, welcome Bonniely, Kristina, ALL OF YOU, your posts make me laugh and smile and give me such strength!  I go for blood counts tomorrow, but feel like they are doing pretty good (not feeling anemic anyway).  I have not had any nausea, but just a nagging, 'rock' feeling in my belly, not hungry most of the time, but when I start to eat, it's ok.  I've found that eating a little bit throughout the day is better than big meals, seems to keep something on the tummy.   And Thank the Lord for Peri-Colace and Benefiber!! (ha)  No mouth sores yet; my oncology nurse gave me a big glass of ice chips and I had to totally freeze my mouth off before and during the adriamycin infusion.... she said the 'frozen mouth' reduces blood flow to the mouth tissue and the chemo doesn't get there as easily because of the reduced blood flow.  Makes good sense to me.  Anyone else get this ice treatment during their sessions?  Is it working? (Also they told me about the 'red pee' too; I would have totally freaked first time I went to the bathroom!! ) Monday coming... new week...new challenges and opportunities.  Remember, when you are feeling your lowest, someone somewhere is thinking of you and lifting you up.   That's so awesome.

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2007 03:30AM TexasKaren wrote: Well, I think I finally hit the bottom... at least I hope it was.  I know each of you has faced this and have had their bad days, but until now, I thought I was strong enough to be 'on top' all the time.  This last session of chemo and neulasta weren't any different than the first, still the same crappy-hurting-tired-beyond-belief feelings... hey, it's CHEMO, ok?  It's poisoning your entire body to irradicate the cancer cells.  It's not supposed to be pleasant.  But, until now I have been blessed with extraordinary health and I'm never sick, so these days of feeling like dog poo-poo over and over finally got to me, and I look like some sort of halloween mask (the hair is going, but it's not gone yet, still tufts hanging on) and my precious hubby had to go to California for a week, so I'm alone with my misery.  So, I finally broke down and had a good cry, curled up in a fetal position and wished that my mommy were here (she's on the other side, but I know she's close to me). And then, today when I felt "human" again and I read about 3 days of postings from all of you, I found myself uplifted again, and given vision of how we all survive and keep going, and I know that I am no less or nor more than all my sisters.  I pray for each of you daily, and extra prayers for those who have difficulties so much more than me.  Evy, your baby is a special soul, I want you know this; he/she will be the greatest joy of your life, and you WILL live a long time to be there as his/her mother (?do you know what baby is, or have I missed something?).  Kristina: your story about Linda gives me proof that keeping my attitude and positive outlook are more important than any pathetic slips into selfish misery.  I have better things to do!!!  Thanks, gals! Question to all on A/C... do you stink?  I mean, has the chemo changed your body odor?  Or is it just our smellers?  I have to take a bath a couple of times a day; I swear I SMELL!  And of course, perfumes don't work either... they stink too!

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2007 05:52AM - edited Nov 15, 2007 06:02AM by TexasKaren ok, my picture didn't work, but I retyped it below - it's not anything special, just some good advice.  Dietary recommendations during chemotherapy       L. Levine, MD - Restrict all vitamins and supplements unless approved by physician. - Nothing raw!   = only exception is bananas, recommend 1-2 a day especiall for patients receiving cisplatin containing regimens  = all vegetables hve to be cooked or steamed  = fruits (except bananas) have to be baked or cooked; baked apples are tasty and very healthy too  = no salads or tomatoes  = no raw onion, Garlic with extreme caution - Dairy   = all raw and unpasteurized mild products should be avoided      - raw milk, buttermilk and cream cheses and unpasteruized soft cheeses    = hard cheeses are fine and are recommended    = yogurt - on the ones that have LIVE cultures (not prepared with live cultures)  Know of only two brands: "Stony Field Farms" and "Dannon", use the Dannon regular, not fat free.  This is also true for frozen yogurt;  no ice cream, unless it is soy or rice. = Other sources of protein: Boost or Ensure, recommend at least one or two a day, they have the perfect proportion of essential amino acids, simple sugars, fats as well as some vitamins and, most important, minerals that are essential for healing.  If nothing else these can be used in cereal instead of milk.  Many patients substitute their morning chocolate drink with the chocolate "Boost".   Also protein mixes from health food stores are fine unless they have excessive vitamins and amino acids. - Meat/Fish   = all well cooked - Avoid greasy and spicy food - Limit alcohol and caffeine - Use stool softeners two to five days after chemotherapy (docusate sodium, "peri-colace")   = anti nausea meds can cause severe constipation; milk of magnesia is preferred, avoid senna based products and 'bulk' laxatives.

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2008 02:49AM TexasKaren wrote: Theresa:   The Emend is wonderful... I had no nausea at all... just like a 'rock' feeling in my tummy all the time, and of course, food didn't smell/taste right at all.  I think a lot of us got terrible heartburn/reflux on A/C too.  I've always had a stomach of iron, but now I'm on protonix for the reflux. I was scheduled for 4 Taxotere every 3 weeks, but my onc says there were studies recently that 12 smaller doses weekly were just as effective and not so many s/e's... I've done well on them.  It's not too late to take some Magnesium and B6.... get the Magnesium Citrate (www.vitaminshoppe.com) not the plain Mag oxide sold in stores.  It will help you through the A/C too.  My onc has a big poster in all the offices on the importance of Mag during all types of chemo as it is one of the important minerals that gets wiped out during this process.  Eat lots of spinach and almonds too.  If you have any lingering neuropathy, it will help it. Glad you're back!  Good luck with the A/C

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2008 12:17PM TexasKaren wrote: WOO HOO!!!  Last Chemo was yesterday!  I can't believe I'm  done.  They gave me a "purple heart" certificate and showered me with confetti.   I brought them all the tote bags I made for each of them that said "Chemo Nurses are Angels in Scrubs" and lots of donuts and kolaches for everyone.  We had a great party! Mexico was so beautiful!  I'll post some pictures in a day or two.  The whales were all over just 300-400 yards from shore! I wanted to stay.  Instead, I got home to a snow storm! It had been 81 on Sunday, by Sun. night when I got in at midnight (after sitting delayed in airports for 7 hours!) the cold had blown through, and by morning it was snowing.  What a contrast! But, I'm glad to be home. I'll be joining you on the next phase of this journey...radiation.  I'm just so happy to be hearing from most of you that you are returning to more or less "normal" and that life is going forward and we are all starting to feel better. Great to hear from Kara, and Karen R. and hope Cheryl had a great vacation too! I, too, am worried about my "chemo brain"...... what am I going to do for an excuse now?!?!?!?!?!?!  haha   I guess I can blame menopause or just old age!
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2008 05:26AM TexasKaren wrote: Evy!  So good to hear from you, even if you aren't doing as well as we'd hoped!  I can't imagine the stress and strain, with two small children and all!  There has to be someone out there to help you; if not a family member, then someone from your church, your pastor, or people at work or in the community.  There are angels out there just waiting for a need that they can serve, you only have to ask.  I don't know where you live, but check with United Way, your hospital auxillary (those ladies who run gift shops and call on patients at hospitals are amazing people!), and your cancer center.   I agree with Linda, DH needs help too.  This disease is just as hard on our husbands as us; on top of it, they think they have to 'be men' and hide a lot of what they are dealing with and it makes it worse.  Get him into some support or therapy or medication.  You are in this together, he needs to recognize that he may need some help too. Don't stop your treatments until you have explored every resource.  If you need help in finding resources, private message me and I'll get to work on it as well.  Also, don't try to be 'supermom"; forget the house.... mine has never been dirtier!!  LOL  I swore I'd "keep everything going", but you know what??  A little dust and dirt in the corners isn't killing us, and now that chemo's over, I may just get around to feeling like cleaning again.  Some things have priority... your children, yourself, and your husband.  The other things can wait.  Keep us informed... we are here for you!!!!
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2008 09:18AM - edited Mar 15, 2008 09:20AM by TexasKaren Hairdressers' secret for making hair grow faster and stronger: Massage your scalp for 5 minutes, from the base of the neck to the front: stimulates blood flow to the scalp, ie, the hair follicles. (Don't do this when shampooing, it is too long for the shampoo to sit on the hair and will dry it out).  There are some electric vibrating devices that have a scalp massage attachment, has little nubs all over it, feels great but tickles too. Exercise:  Cardiovascular exercise, again, increasing blood flow all over the body Eat nutritionally (I think we are all trying to do that)! FACT: Hair grows slower in cold weather!!  Wait for spring and you'll see a difference! Karen R:  Great on starting the next phase: Radiation therapy!  Ulla: Glad to hear you are on #19 and just now getting red. My onc told me it takes a couple of weeks usually.  Yes, it feels like a sunburn, even if you're not red; that's why we have to be so careful of our skin.  She gave me some Auquafor..it's made by Eucerin and sold in drugstores, it's like vasoline though.  Don't know if I can handle that on my skin!  I use a natural/organic lotions from Burt's Bees...one that is rather stinky but is amazing, "Healthy Healing, Carrot Nutritive" (the bad smell goes away after it absorbs), and "Thoroughly Therapeutic, Honey & Orange Wax", it's great too, but very thick and hard to get out of the bottle (it's the wax, I'm sure!)  I'm going to keep using these with Aloe Vera gel.

Posts.Content: May 5, 2008 12:31PM TexasKaren wrote: Deb:  I too, have finally had some "burning" show up.  Again, like you, it is over my collar bone and along the top of my back.  I only have nine more to go, and my doc said I've done very well.  I've been reading the February radiation thread all along, and I'm amazed at how some have had real problems.  Hang in there; I think you and I will be fine.  The red will go away fairly quick.  The only time you get "scarring" is when it blisters and sores form, and I doubt we get that.  Keep using the aquafor, all day and all night.  My red areas ITCH!!  I noticed that it got better just by having two days off over the weekend. Our big gig at the air force base was fun.  We had the usual technical problems (you just can't have all this electric stuff, amps, speakers, instruments, lights, etc without some problems all the time!!), but the only really bad part was when the wing commander got up to speak and introduce the event and thank everyone and the sound system went dead... LOL!   There was about 1,000 there.  At least the weather was good; we'd been having 40 mph winds on Weds and Thurs and temps in the 90's, but it was 78 and light breezes on Fri.  I did get a little sunburn, and my DH fell down on his butt and has a lovely purple bum today!  LOL  I laugh, because it's usually ME who does those things... my middle name is "grace". If anyone else out there wants a "surprise"... please PM me with your address!!!  Ulla: be patient; Sweden is a bit further for the mailman to go!

Posts.Content: May 8, 2008 12:01PM TexasKaren wrote: I found the coolest poem today from another cancer survivor.  I'm going to finish my little talk on Survivors' Day with it:  It was written in 1997.  I just had to share it with you all! THE BIG 'C' The big 'C' I heard someone call it. Another just whispered the word. That we don't even dare to say "cancer" out loud It gives it power it doesn't deserve. So I'm giving that letter new meaning And refusing to give in to fear By reclaiming the power for you and for me And by saying these words loud and clear: Let the "C" be for "Cure" and "Compassion." Let it stand for the "Candles" we light, And a "Chorus" of voices shouting, "You CAN"! To all who will take up this fight. Let the "C" be for "Cash Contribution" "Credit" or Check" will work, too. Let it stand for "Commitment" and Checkups" and "Cheer," And the "Children" "Counting" on you. Let it mean that we know our "Creator" Is beside us each step of the way, And remind us to "Call" on His strength and His love And to "Celebrate" every new day. To everyone facing this "Challenge," I say it's a fight we can win. Tell all who will listen that, starting today, The "C' is for "Courage," my friends.

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2008 03:46AM TexasKaren wrote: Lori..Thanks for the website!  There is no way that there is a place where you can 'figure out your future' or what your own individual prognosis is, but it's nice to know that you have the power to see what your treatment options are, the statistics for survival based on those treatments, etc.  Everyday they are coming up with more and more information and new treatments.  We, as cancer patients, live in a very exciting time when a "cure" may be coming for many types of cancer.    I just read today that the bone drug Zometa may help cancer patients who have bone mets (who are pre-menopausal) survive longer!  Great news.  They had a suspicion of some action from incidental occurrences, but then they did a trial, and it helped in some 30% of patients!  http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20080531/ap_on_he_me/med_breast_cancer_bone_drug_3 About the soy... I'm trying to avoid HFCS (high fructose corn syrup)... it's in everything too!!  Just try to eat as much natural, organic fresh foods as you can and try not to use the packaged, processed foods.  But you are right... the jury is not entirely decided on what soy does to cancers yet....too many conflicting studies. Have a great weekend!!!

Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2008 10:53AM TexasKaren wrote: Sue:  Beating Cancer with Nutrition by Patrick Quillin, available at Amazon.com.   It's almost going 'vegan', all organic, etc, but, I've adopted several of the strategies.  I can't go all the way... what, give up coffee?!?!?!  NEVER.  ha  The trick is to eat as healthy as possible, and really give up the processed food with all the preservatives, and try to be as healthy as you can.  All of his scientific study quotations are scary though... we really are killing ourselves with our Western lifestyle and diet!!  I've increased my fruits and veggies a lot and only eat red meat once a week, fish twice, and veggie dinners 1-2 times a week.  Hubby is fine with it, and so is my 33 year old son, so I must be cooking ok for them!  I'm still working on the sugar and the caffeine, but I've cut down a whole lot.  Deep breathing and exercise too...I'm back in the gym 4 days a week.    During the last three months of 'eating better', my blood sugars have dropped (I was approaching borderline pre-diabetes when I had my surgery) and my cholesterol has dropped too! Hey, has anyone checked out Oprah's "21-day Cleanse" at (www.oprah.com).  It's a vegan thing too (no gluten, no animal products, no caffeine or sugar or alcohol), but I'm doing a 10 day one at the end of the month.  Will let you know what happens.  She's been talking it up on TV a lot.  Supposed to really clean out all the toxins and restore your digestive system.

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2008 12:11AM TexasKaren wrote: KARA:  haha.... yea, after all you've gone through, Miss Clairol shouldn't be a scary thing at all!!!  It's easy... you'll do just fine.  Just like shampooing your hair, only you leave it on for 20 mins.  Just remember, your hair is VERY baby-like, do not leave it on for longer than recommended! Here's a LOVELY thought I got in my email... Thank you ALL for being in the fabric of the quilt of my life!!! GIRLS IN MY CIRCLE   When I was little, I used to believe in the concept of one best friend, And then I started to become a woman. And then I found out that if you allow your heart to open up, God would show you the best in many friends. One friend is needed when you're going through things with your man. Another friend is needed when you're going through things with your mom. Another will sit beside you in the bleachers as you delight in your children and their activities. Another when you want to shop, share, heal, hurt, joke, or just be. One friend will say, 'Let's cry together,' Another , 'Let's fight together,' Another , 'Let's walk away together.' One friend will meet your spiritual need, Another your shoe fetish, Another your love for movies, Another will be with you in your season of  confusion, Another will be your clarifier, Another the wind beneath your wings. But whatever their assignment in your life,  On whatever the occasion, On whatever the day, Or wherever you need them to meet you with their gym shoes on and hair pulled back, Or to hold you back from making a complete fool of yourself .. Those are your best friends. It may all be wrapped up in one woman, But for many, it's wrapped up in several..  One from 7th grade, One from high school,  Several from the college years, a couple from old jobs, On some days your mother,  On some days your neighbour, On others, your sisters, And on some days, your daughters. (And many days, the October 2007 Chemo Girls!!) So whether they've been your friend for 20 minutes or 20 years,   Pass this on to the women that God has placed in your life To make a difference.

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2007 01:18PM TexasKaren wrote: Ladies with the runs!!  BRAT DIET:  Bananas, rice, applesauce and toast.... good 'stoppers' for diarrhea.  It follows the  diarrhea advice by pediatric doctors, so those of you with kids will know it.   And, these are easy on the tummy/nausea as well. I have found the cutest little crocheted caps at Family Dollar store (yea, I know, even cheaper than Wal-Mart) and they look and feel great.  I will wear at night when my head is cold, but I wore one this weekend out too.  I still have hair, but it's falling and short and my ears and neck are cold!   I have a new thing too.  I could never have pierced ears because of metal allergies.  I wear 'ear screws', the old fashioned ones, occasionally, but they hurt.  I recently found ear cuffs... these just fit on the outside of your ear, over the fat cartilege part, and they look great.  I plan to wear a lot of them now that my ears are showing! Angie:  the dance team & moms will embrace you and support you ... you will be amazed at the reception.  And appetite?  I know it's the steroids, but after my 4x days of feeling bad and food not appealing at all (tasted weird too!) following the first chemo, my appetite returned with a vengenance.  I've been a piggy too! Treatment #2 went fine today... tired and loopy, gonna hit the sack.  Hugs to all and hope that everyone has a better day tomorrow ! !

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2007 01:44AM TexasKaren wrote: Welcome Lori!  Hope you continue to do well and thanks for the ginger advice.  I have been drinking ginger ale too. I am on my first neulasta day after round 2.  Feel puny, but not untolerable.  Have done better this round than last, and it wasn't that bad, except days 3-4 with the neulasta laying me out (4 days out of 14 feeling rough, after that I felt good).  The aches are being controlled with Aleve and hot baths.  Tummy is upset, but not real nausea, just not hungry, hard rock in bottom of it feeling.  I found my armpit lump in late July, had mammo/us and tests and then lumpectomy on Aug. 21, then all the consults and scans, etc, and started chemo on Oct. 15.  Would have started Oct 1, but we went on a cruise to Mexico!  I'm on A/C x 4 every two weeks, then 4 weekly of T/C, then radiation after the New Year. I had two full handfuls of hair in the tub this morning.... keeping my little hairnets/caps on and brushing/plucking frequently.  When I look like a rabid squirrel (like Hammy in Over the Hedge!) by Friday I'll go have my hairdresser shave it.  At the rate it's going, there won't be much there in two more days!  My son (33) was laughing at it this morning...it's thin!  FUNNY NOTE: The grey at the temples and front where my color had grown out fell out first... that's one way to get the grey out!  Kristina: glad you're hanging in there.  I feel the same. It's hard during the 'bad days', but then you feel better.  Thanks to all of you for your encouragement and support.  It makes it do-able!

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2007 02:13AM TexasKaren wrote: Kara, Karen, Cheryl, Debbie, Ulla, Lori, and all! I have emerged from the pits of neulasta/A/C hell.  This was the last time.  Every A/C chemo cycle was a little worse.  It's so very hard when you're in the midst of feeling like something you never imagined you'd feel like to keep a positive attitude.  I am a very positive person, but I found myself in each of these chemo weeks to be anything BUT positive, no matter how hard I tried.  When the body that you've been used to for your whole life goes on strike against you and your emotions and hormones and the drugs all stack up against you, it's just almost impossible to rise above all of it.  BUT, each passing hour...each passing day, brings some relief, some abatement of the symptoms.  One morning, you wake up and realize that, hey, that pain is gone...that stomach problem is less...that feeling of desperation is gone.  Lift your hands in the air at those moments and say "HALLALUJAH! I am going to make it again!" and thank God for seeing you through it.  Don't ever feel guilty for feeling 'pissy' or blue.  WE HAVE THE RIGHT!   But, we don't have the right to lay around in that feeling and let us swallow us up though.  Keep fighting, keep your eyes on the next day..the next week, and just like all those who have gone before us, we will make it!!  We will heal, we will continue to live and love life, and we will be stronger women for it. Tues, Weds and Thurs were hell.... Today I am HUMAN again !!!  I will survive!!!  (dancing like Donna Summers.....ha) Ulla:   Give your body time to heal.... be patient, it will get better!  It has undergone a huge attack, not only the surgery, but the chemo too.  Take the days that don't hurt and be glad for them.  Take the days of pain and file them away under, 'the next day will be better'~ Unfortunately, now that I feel better, I have a PILE of work on my desk to get to.... ugh...

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2007 12:25AM TexasKaren wrote: Hi girls!!  Sorry for not being around.... ice storm took out our internet tower again for 3 days.  Sheesh.  So much for the perks of having a T1.  Had my first Taxotere yesterday.  I have been misinformed. LOL  I thought I was going to get four rounds of A/C and four of Taxotere.  BUT, yesterday I was informed I'm getting 12 weekly rounds of Taxotere, so I won't be done with chemo until end of February.  What makes that ok?  My onc said that they have found that using 12 reduced doses weekly with less steroids and no neulasta needed has far less side effects than the 4 big doses of Taxotere given every 3 weeks.  So... I'm ok with that.  I felt fine yesterday and very good today.  I'm sure this stuff will be cumulative, like they all are, so I expect I'll pick up more s/e's as the treatments go on, but I think this will be SO MUCH better than the A/C.  I didnt' even have "steroid loopies" yesterday.  Course, they give you a bunch of benedryl...so I slept all the way home.  LOL Coach and Hotmedic:  We seem to be close on cycle.  I'm reading your posts carefully to see what's ahead for me! Kristina, Karyll, Deb:  PRAYERS daily double dosing for you!!!  I'm so sorry you are having hard times and all these complications!!!  I actually feel guilty for feeling good when so many of you AREN'T!!! Lori:  Thank you for giving us a head's up on that....we'll be better prepared.  It's common after big weddings or other big life events too, you know, all the tension, stress, etc that you live with for weeks, and then bam, when it's over, CRASH. Hate it:  Hang in there honey!!  I met a lady yesterday who absolutely dreads/fears her chemos, and she's got a lot to go (ovarian ca).  When she gets there, to distract her from all the anticipatory panic, she puts on a sleep mask that she sprays with one of those 'relaxing/calming' scents that doesn't make her sick and plugs in her mp3 player and she says that way she can 'go into her own world and not be in that place' for a few hours.  Try anything to distract yourself.  Tell the nurses to squeeze a little lemon on top of your ice chips to make them tastier.  But, they do work... I never have had a single mouth sore...they are worth it!!! Hugs to Evy and Ulla and all the rest and hope I got everything right!!!!   Cheryl:  My cold has hung on for 14 days now... just that naggy old lingering cough.  Hope yours goes away faster than that!!

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2008 09:38AM TexasKaren wrote: Welcome Susan!  Great news Nicki that you aren't having any s/e's yet.  Hang in there.  I didn't have many, except the neulasta shot kicked my butt, and food got weirder as the treatments went on, but after the A/C was over, I'm pretty much back to normal on the Taxotere and feeling rather well except for constant constipation and sometimes a 'rock' in my tummy.   #4 Taxotere went well yesterday; I have another cold so the benedryl with it enabled me to get a clear head and sleep for the 2 hour treatment     Hubby has it too, so we both kept each other awake last night coughing.  UGH.  I haven't had a cold in nearly 10 years, and now I've had two in two months.   I am NOT used to feeling bad and it pisses me off ! ! !  (ok, my ranting is over)  My onc told me to start taking olive leaf oil extract next time I feel the sniffles coming on... he said it is a great anti-viral agent, better than echineachea. Kristina!  Glad to hear from you... sorry about hubby's surgery, and he's on my prayer list too for good recovery!   I have no control over Texas weather, but the saying here that everyone lives by is "Just wait a minute, and the weather will change!".  Being a TV weatherman in Texas is the best job ever... you can be entirely wrong in your forecast and you won't get fired, because the weather is so goofy here.  It was 18 degrees yesterday morning when I headed out for my treatment.... it will only do that a couple days a year, THANKFULLY!!! My internet was down again over the weekend.... I missed you all!! Glad everyone is getting back to work!!  I've got a ton to do myself.  I have found that maybe working from home is NOT a good idea... it's too easy to talk yourself into taking a nap instead of working through the day!!! Lori and Kristina:  Keep me posted about rads as I will be starting too in March; good to read about your experiences, and from other's I've talked to, it's not really bad. Ulla:  Hugs to your hubby and hope you are doing better, hon!

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2008 01:24AM TexasKaren wrote: Ok, I may have lied when I said I feel good on the taxotere.....  I think it's accumulative effects are starting to build up.  Onc says he'll give me an extra week off in between #6 next Mon and #7 for a rest.  I thought, why?, and I think I know now.  Fatigue is worsening, tummy problems starting up again like the A/C crap, and taste is going away again too.   Anyone else on the weekly Taxotere starting to notice these things?  I'm trying NOT to be depressed about it, but we all know that you can't wish yourself to feel good when you don't.  Sigh.... Ok, that's my 'whining' for the day.  Debbie, I'm so sorry about your uncle.  But, I know that he is up there watching over you now.. in his jeans.  (Funny, but around here, there are a bunch I've known who are buried in their best, starched jeans...but it's Texas!).  Hope you feel better today!  I sympathize with your concerns over your deductibles too... I think we're all there.  My first treatment of the new year ate up all the money in my health savings account, so the next two chemos are on me. LOL  But after that I go back into my lifetime fund at 100%.  I can't imagine the stress on people who do not have adequate insurance.  Like my DH says, first we pay the house, buy food, then electricity and gas, and then the docs get paid....   We talk about that in our cancer support group; how some people have stem cell transplants, and others don't and die, just because some have insurance and others don't.  Sad situation in this country. Angels!!!  I love my angels.... everyone around me, my friends and family, and those who I know and feel are 'above' me watching and interceeding for me, and all of YOU!!!  You are my angels too!  And you are all over the place, even Sweden, Indiana, Colorado, Canada, California, Ohio, New Hampshire...etc!!!   I am so BLESSED! HUGS and have a good day!! PS:  The nutrition info is kind of large, so I'm going to start a blog somewhere and link you to it instead of filling up our little group here!
