Waves:  The steriods always make me feel higher and loopier than a kite!  I can't concentrate or think or focus or anything, and they make my vision blurry the first day too.  I'd say something about the 'good ol days' back in the 60's, but I say I never inhaled... (!lol).  They also make me bloat up like a frog.. I swear I add 2 inches to my waist/tummy each time and it takes a week to get rid of it.  I think it paralyzes my intestines; or the antiemetics do it, but I know that it takes me a good 5 days to get the plumbing going again right. I've been reading the new nutrition book and it is FABULOUS!  It takes all the pieces of what other diet philosophies I've been reading about and ties it all together, and it's sensible and do-able.  I would like each of you in the group to get a copy.  If you can't buy one yourselves, PM me and I'll get one for you from this guy in Abilene and mail it to you.  He's got a whole ministry going and they get these books at half price.  It's available through www.amazon.com too, in fact it was the best selling book of 1999.  His credentials are impeccable.   BEATING CANCER WITH NUTRITION, 2005, Patrick Quillin   It's got great recipes in it too and an audio cd. The man from Abilene that does this is Dale Morrison and his website is:  www.hopeandhelp.ws

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2008 11:05AM TexasKaren wrote: I can't really believe it......!!   Just think... only a few months ago, we were all just finding each other, and beginning our "October 2007 Chemo Girls" thread.  We were full of fear, panic, uncertainty and dread.  Now, several are finished, or finishing soon!!!  After all our weeks of thinking there is no end in sight, it appears!! I still have 6 more weekly treatments... but I'm already starting a list of things I won't miss:   I want EVERYONE to contribute to this and we'll post it out there somewhere.  I think there is a poetry/story thread?  Anyway: The END OF CHEMO  - I will rejoice! No more weekly appointments to dread No more pokes and needles No more steroids that make me weird and emotional and bloated No more anti-emetics that make me constipated and bloated No more dreading how bad I'll feel after chemo No more realizing my dread was true and actually feeling really crappy the next few days or longer No more aches and pains all over every inch of me No more fatigue No more funny tasting food No more hair falling out No more freezing cold bald head No more weepy, teary, gooey eyes No more ringing in the ears No more feeling like I'm inhabited by an alien No more being afraid of going into public and catching something No more being afraid of eating something that my tummy won't tolerate No more being afraid of the next, new side effect I haven't gotten yet NO MORE BEING AFRAID I CAME......... I CONQUERED.......I WILL MOVE ON I WILL MISS: 1)         My angelic chemo nurses 2)         The warm blankets they get you when you're cold sitting there for hours 3)         Talking with the other chemo patients and finding new friends 4)         Having a lot of energy from the steroids! 5)         Blaming all my shortcomings on "chemo"...  I'll just have to fess up and take responsibility again for myself! 6)         Being able to wear anything on my head and not worrying about how my hair looks (in a way I will miss being bald!) --------------------- How about it?   Let me know what else we need to add, as all our experiences have been different!

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2008 02:26PM TexasKaren wrote: Kristina:   I am praying so hard tonight... and will be in the days ahead.  I know that prayer works.  And I believe that you chose the name "HopefulKristina" not out of chance or just on a whim.   Please don't give up on yourself!!  Others aren't.  We'll be with you all the way.   NEVER give in or give up!! I have a little story to share.  I met a beautiful lady just last week after chemo when I was getting my oil in my car changed.  I say beautiful, because her little 1/2" of fuzzy hair was just a little longer than mine is now.  After introducing ourselves and both telling that  we have breast cancer, she told me she was diagnosed a little over a year ago.  She was in the last part of her chemotherapy about 6 months ago when she started having severe headaches and they discovered it had metastisized to her brain....even during chemo!   She has three tumors in there.  She told me that she prayed for three days and nights before she decided to make a trip to the Cancer Center of America in Illinois.  They paid her airplane ticket and she spent two weeks there undergoing all sorts of tests.  She was actually leaving the next day (last Tues) to go back with her son and have brain surgery.  They told her that if they could get most of the tumor out, then they would begin chemo again and with their other treatments they can give her a lot more time; even beat it.   As I was listening to her, I was found myself wondering what I would do if they found it somewhere even before I was done with all my treatments??  What would I do?  I hate chemo!  I have thought before that if this comes back, would I go through all this again?  I was watching her face as she talked, and all of a sudden, she grabbed my hand, almost like she KNEW what I was thinking, and she looked at me with the most radiant look in her eyes, and said, 'I don't know what the future holds, I don't know if they can cure me or not, but I believe in them and I trust in my Lord to help me through each and every day that I have left, and I realize that I may have a few months, or a few years, but I also know that I could be killed in a car crash or have a heart attack and die tomorrow... and whatever it takes, I want to be here for my children and my grandchildren until my Lord tells me in true spirit that I have fought the good fight and it's time to let go".    I couldn't do anything but give her a big hug and tell her I'd be praying for her too.  And I have been, every day.   And I'm praying for each of us too, and Kristina has been moved to the top of the list. It's a long story, I know.. but I just know that she was right.  I see it in the chemo room and in my WHIMS group too.  I see the people who are going through it all again...for the third or fourth time... and who STILL HAVE THE COURAGE to go on living and fighting!  I see Julie, who weighs about 80 pounds and doesn't have hardly any internal organs left because of all the surgeries she's had in battling ovarian cancer for the past 10 years... but... she's had 10 years and she's still going!  And she laughs, and she loves, and she lives and she says, "Every day is a gift from God, and I celebrate it". Dearest Kristina:  DON'T GIVE UP.... and don't give in to the thought that you haven't beaten it.... just say you haven't beaten it YET!!!

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2008 12:26AM TexasKaren wrote: ULLA!  Welcome back and HAPPY BELATED BIRTHDAY!!  Don't worry about the weight...your body is changing daily and give it time and keep at the healthy eating and exercise, and you'll see a difference.  Dont' get discouraged.  I am kind of scared of this radiation thing too, but then I read everything from others going/gone through it and everyone says it's ok.  It's just scary to think they are bombarding your body (especially around your chest area, heart, lungs) with these invisible beams of stuff!  I bet the lotion helps to prevent the 'sunburn' effect and the people I've read say that you get some degree of 'sun' damage on your skin, like, leathery, like you've been a sunbather for years.  So I'm sure the more lotion you can put on all the time will help with that.  How about those of you doing it now?  Do you use lots of lotion too? I had #10 Taxotere yesterday -- only 2 more to go!  It kicked my butt yesterday though, but I'm ok today.  I see my surgeon for followup today and I know we'll talk about radiation and I'll get my Rx for my compression sleeve  (two weeks till Mexico!) Love, hugs, and prayers for everyone, esp Kristina!

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2008 12:58AM TexasKaren wrote: Ulla:  Sorry your time is being consumed with radiation; but on the bright side, it doesn't last near as long as the chemotherapy did!!  It will be over soon, in fact, your spring in Sweden should be a lovely time for you because you'll be finished with it all!!  Hair?  Mine too... it is growing, but seems very slow.  But, if you study about hair, healthy hair/people's hair grows about 1 inch a month.  You are still getting the 'chemo' out of your body, and now having the radiation too.  It will grow, just give it time, and about 6 months from now, you'll know you have hair again because you'll have to go to the beautician and get it shaped and trimmed!   About sugars; fruits (and dates) are natural sugars.  They are ok.  They just say to watch and not eat a ton of fruit, ie, one apple (apples have a lot of fructose) a day is fine, four isn't.  It's all about moderation.... Cheryl:  the SNOW!!  I miss big snows (but not the cold).  When I was small in Colorado, my dad used to throw us off the porch into the big drifts and then pretend he was cold and going back in the house and we would be yelling and screaming, then he'd come dig us out and 'save us'.    I love making snowmen too!   BUT, I also understand about not being able to go anywhere either!!   Folks are saying this is the last of the bad winter.... we'll see.

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2008 05:28AM TexasKaren wrote: Ulla:  My hair is all sorts of color too.  I was told by my support group here that the pigment cells are the last to start growing again... the hair follicles don't know what color they are for awhile.  Many told me that they started out with grey/blond/brown mixes, but after a few months, the pigment kicked in and they were brown again.  I guess we all just have to be very patient!!!

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2008 12:26AM TexasKaren wrote: My "marks" all disappeared in a few days, and she said I could take them off with baby oil sooner if I wanted, they will remark me each session (they are like semi-permanent markers, they do come off), but I don't have any real high on my neck or anything, that I know of, but don't start my treatments until 4/1.  I only have the one very small freckle tatoo in between my boobies that will be permanent.  Right now it's real black but they said it will fade like tatoos do and just look like a tiny mole. YES, I'm back to shaving legs... I really didn't miss that!!  My one armpit too (funny, the one they took all the nodes out of doesn't seem to grow much hair?)  I am having problems with my eyelashes too... only half of them came out, so now, I have some REAL long ones and these tiny itty bitty new ones growing in.  Makes putting on mascara very interesting!!  I'm thinking of trimming the long ones because they look like   ''II'''II'''   Wierd.   Hair is growing slowly, we just have to be patient.  Remember when your babies were little bitty and it seemed like forever for them to get enough hair to get a haircut?  (Well, my sons anyway... they were very bald and took forever to get hair; my oldest son was almost 2 before he got his first haircut!) Sue:  Sure hope they figure out what is going on with your hip.  I'm praying hard for you with all these other tests; it is scary, but have faith!  Kara went through that bad scare too (or was it Karyll? chemo brain..) Don't be afraid of adding radiation therapy; if it can further 'wipe out' these cancer cells in our bodies, it's worth it, and it's a lot less toxic than chemo.  Deb, don't know why they just say 6-7 weeks and can't tell you more specifically.. LOL  I've been told 25 treatments and then 8 boosters to my nodes because they were 8/14 positive.  So, I'm basically looking at 6 weeks too and a couple extra. I am going totally 'nekked' now (my head... LOL)  It is getting too warm for wigs and hats, and now that I have a tiny bit of hair, they actually itch and sweat more.    My step-sons were here for spring break a couple of days this week and they loved my hair, said I really looked "COOL".   So, I've decided to go bareheaded next week when I put on my big annual Ob/Gyn state meeting as well.  Most of the doctors on my board know I have bc anyway; it will be a surprise to the others, but, hey, they are doctors, and they are the sweetest in the world.  Everyone loves their Ob/Gyn, right?   Besides, I have this great t-shirt to wear on Saturday (informal day) that says "I'm Too Sexy For My Hair".  :))) EVERYONE HAVE A BLESSED EASTER AND MAY GOD'S LOVE SURROUND YOU AND FILL YOU WITH RENEWAL AND GRACE!!!

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2008 02:32AM TexasKaren wrote: WOW... I go away for a few days, and you gals add pages and pages to catch up on...   Cheryl, glad your surgery went well, sorry about the anesthesia complications (nausea).  Everyone's hair is growing good!  I'll post one of me too. My meeting was very good, but exhausting (they are even without being ill this year!) and I must have climbed 1,000 stairs during it; my knees hurt so bad yesterday I couldn't even move!  I got my radiation block dry-run testing yesterday and start radiation this afternoon.  I'm marked up all over too, but, it's temporary. Funny, I went 'au naturel' at the meeting and everyone loved it.  A couple of female doctors even told me I need to keep my hair this short !  Ha, never happen! But it was encouraging.  I stopped wearing anything on my head two weeks ago.  It is growing very fast now, and has a few signs of maybe being curly when it gets a little longer.  We'll see!  Karen and Lori, you're short look is great on you, and everyone else looks good too!  Ulla, don't worry about the dark hair... you're natural color will come back after awhile.  Just be glad you aren't all grey and silver like some of us ! ! ! I'm going to go play with my camera phone and see if I can get a picture here too.... It was 92 here yesterday and 68 today...My tulips and irises can't figure out what to do. PS:  I lost a filling too.... my dentist said that during chemo our tooth enamel is weakened and you start to get small cavities under/around your existing fillings, which weakens them and makes them loose or fall out.  He said I was lucky if I only lost one and didn't have any other problems.

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2008 05:42AM TexasKaren wrote: Kara "Glowing Girl"  Can he see you in the dark??  haha Yes, the area right on top of my incision is still hard, but the rest has softened considerably.  Scar tissue won't ever get back to 'normal', but a thin line is better than a hard two inch wide 'seam' over my boob! The board is quiet.. I believe that everyone is feeling better and getting on with getting on!  I planted spinach and flowers today; it's 88 out there (was 65 two days ago) and hot.  I have to watch the sun now that I'm in radiation, but I sure love it.  I should have had my spinach in by March, but I am just now feeling like I'm my old self energy wise.  The brain, however, still is stuck in "chemo brain" mode.  I fear that it is permanent    If I don't write something down, it's gone.  I have little sticky notes everywhere...... My hair is suddenly going VERY curly!  I actually complained for the first time in months last night when getting ready to go play with the band that "my hair won't cooperate!".... I had to gel it down over my ears, little curls want to pop straight out sideways.  It's so funny and so totally different than my hair has EVER been, I look in the mirror and wonder who the heck that is? Hope everyone is enjoying the first of a beautiful spring... my lilac tree is all bloomed out and it smells like new beginnings... and I know it is for ALL of us my sweet sisters!!  The long, cold, miserable winter is OVER, we conquered and survived, and now we can rejoice!

Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2008 09:31AM TexasKaren wrote: What a great weekend... hope everyone had a wonderful one. Hey ladies, I actually had enough hair this morning to comb it into the center and have a "Baby Mohawk".  My step son, son and DH laughed their heads off at me, but it's kind of cute.  In my baby pics, my mom used to take my hair, finger comb it into the middle and make a curl around her finger running down the top of my head.  I figure she's still doing that from the other side now. LOL Someone asked about the 'speaking' thing at the Survivors' Day.  It's on June 2, so I have a month to try to make a speech up where I won't cry in the middle of it.  I always get teary eyed when I have to do something emotional!   I don't have to make it long, fortunately!  Thank you to all of you who have been giving me things you'd say and think about... you are all so wonderful! Tomorrow is our WHIMS (cancer support group) 2nd anniversary party and we're all going to a restaurant for mexican food because it's Cinco de Mayo (a BIG DEAL here in Texas, for sure!!).  I'm also having tamales and stuff at the nursing home with my mom-in-law tomorrow at lunch for their festival, so by Tuesday morning, I'll be bloated and have gained 5 pounds from eating Mexican food all day!  LOL   Linda:  So sorry your disability is over and you have to go back to work!   I've become very complacent about my job, and that's bad... Deb:  I've got two coffee cans full of sea shells.... I'm going to start going through my house room by room when I get all done with rads and start cleaning out.  Anyone else having wierd urges like this??  I already warned my DH that this fall we're having a HUGE garage sale!

Posts.Content: May 6, 2008 04:25AM TexasKaren wrote: Ulla and Cheryl:   I'm sorry that you have to keep taking drugs for the next few years... but actually, you are among the fortunate.  They have very good scientific data now on the estrogen/HER positive cancers, and these new drugs (Taxol and Herceptin) are making a huge difference in the survival rate of these patients.  And, overall, they aren't that hard on you (other than premature menopause).  I kinda wish I was in your group.  I'm a "triple negative", negative ER/PR and HER.  My cancer is therefore not receptive to any of the new drugs, and it is also more agressive; hence why I had a little tiny tumor but 8/14 positive nodes.  The good news is a recent study they did said that the 12 weekly treatments of Taxotere (like I got) were more effective than the 4 huge doses every three weeks that they used to give ( added +2-3% to the survival rate).  So, I'm up to 87% chance of surviving... heck, I'm 56 (soon), so that gives me at least another 40 years, right?!?!  LOL Off for rads...then my mexican dinner with the WHIMS group.... (I already had tamales, tortillas and beans/rice for lunch..mmmm!)  Don't you wish you lived in Texas?  VAYA CON DIOS, MY SISTERS!

Posts.Content: May 24, 2008 01:00PM TexasKaren wrote: Ulla:   Sorry about Erik, but you found him a good home, and you can still see him when you want.  I'm sorry your DH has changed, but I can understand his 'changing'... he also has faced losing you and is trying to deal with it.  You haven't been married too long, have you?  I dare say that if our DH's came home and told us they had cancer or something, we'd turn into very clingy, insecure, psychotic messes too!  Cancer affects everyone we know, especially our spouses and children.  Did you know that our spouses feel a great deal of anxiety and even guilt over our cancers??  I was surprised to read an article about how they feel like they have to DO SOMETHING to make it all better for us, but they can't.  Especially men... they have always been the 'strong' ones, and now they are totally helpless to help us.  I talked to my DH and he agreed... it's very hard on them.  Mine was extremely angry at my cancer at first...he watched his father and brother die from very bad cancers (advanced colon and renal cell cancers) and he just wouldn't believe me when I told him that I would beat this one and I wasn't going to die a horrible death.  His biggest fear was the chemo I was going to take.  20 years ago when his father and then later his brother went through chemo for their very bad cancers, the chemo was horrible, terrible and almost killed them faster than the cancers did.  He was terrified for me and it affected his sleep, his work, etc.  It took a great deal of time and education to make him see that it's different nowadays.   I know your DH loves you more than anything...!  That's why he's acting a little selfish like a little boy.  He's not even going to let that cancer, or a cat, take you away! ! !     (and yes, we are our husband's mother at times too, aren't we gals!!) Hey, your new meds are decreasing your appetite?  Send me some!  LOL   I'm back on my almost vegetarian, no sugar diet (or trying!) ...got to lose this 15 pounds or else!!!   I'm glad it's summer and I can get good produce again.  I'm rambling... OFF TO BED!  Everyone have a great Memorial Day weekend, and remember those who died for our freedom and those who fight today to keep it!

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2008 12:25AM TexasKaren wrote: Thank you Joy.  All her children are grown, thankfully.  She was older than my son by 15 years, but they had an incredible connection and you just knew from being around them that their love was meant to be, no matter the age difference.  He's struggling to find his way right now, the rug was yanked from underneath him, but he knows that she'll be watching over him and still guiding him to find himself and his future again.  It will be hard, but it will be alright. The hard part for all of us is the suddeness of it.  I think that as we've all dealt with cancer, we've certainly thought often of what we need to do, what to say, what business to take care of in the event that we don't survive this disease, no matter how positive and "I'm going to beat it" we say we are.  Still...those thoughts are there.  Dying suddenly is a lot different than having some time to take care of all those things.  I lost my father years ago to a sudden heart attack, no warning, and it took a long time to get over that and deal with not having time to say goodbye, I should have gone to see him the month before instead of going camping, etc.  That's the hardest part.  All the unfinished business, the un-said things.  So, I guess the bottom line is like they always say.... tell the ones around you that you love them every day, and in every way.  You just never know......

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2009 02:56AM TexasKaren wrote: Love your picture on the rod!  Glad your son has a lead on some work.  My son is still "Mr. Mom" for now.  He sounds really tired when I talk to him... .LOL!!!!  I'm sorry your neck is bothering you; yes, the cold is bad.  My fingers have been hurting and stiff; I've never had any arthritis symptoms until Taxotere.  I've had really good results from taking the 1500 Glucosamine/Chondritin/MSM (Osteo BioFlex Maximum or Triple is best for the money, only 2 pills a day).  I started my hubby on it about 2 years ago; he's got strong family hx of arthritis and being a guitar player, his hands were really acting up, to the point he couldn't move one finger!   It really helped him so when I started hurting bad after Taxotere in wrist and knees, I started taking it too, and I hardly notice it now; but it takes a good 6 weeks to get into your system and start repairing/oiling those joints.  We can tell if we skip a couple of days of pills....Try it, but again, you'll have to stay on it to see the benefits. Our bad cold snap is over... back in the 50's-60's again.  I feel for all of you in IN, KY, TN, OH... I hope you all have power and are staying in snug and warm!!  Two days of 14-24 here is impossibly ridiculous for Texas!!!   Living in Tucson would be really nice............ LOL!!!

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2012 04:24PM TexasKaren wrote: I bought a powder to put in the water to alkalize it... works great. Bought the Ph test strips also.  A lot of lemon in your water will help, but not raise is to the levels you need, but it helps.  But, diet is more important than water.. you can undo your alkylizing water with just eating the wrong foods.  Read "The Alkalyzing Diet" books under search in Amazon... gives lots of info. One by Istvan Fazekas, one by Vadim Guchinskiy ... both good, the first is easier to read and has more recipes

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2011 05:02AM TexasKaren wrote: Triple negative is so difficult.... there are not many treatment options out there, because they don't have any of the hormonal receptors.  It is great that she has had 9 months on this trial.  I have not heard of Arumbicin, but many of the trial drugs we don't hear of.  If you trust her oncologist and she is being treated at a major cancer center (which usually are the ones doing trials), then I'd go on to the next one and hope for another good response. I have been on 3 "staple" chemos that didn't work since my disease returned in Dec, 2010, and am on my fourth.  If this one fails, I will be looking at going into trials myself.  Anything to give us some more time.

I am wearing one of those paper sleeping caps so it doesn't fall over the house!  GROS.. just glad I cut it short a week ago.  I go outside and stand upwind and do my "plucking a chicken" session a couple times of day (it's very windy here in west Texas, so it flies away nicely).  Onc nurses who gave me my shot today said it'll probably be all gone by this weekend.  Oh fun! LOL  Better than the FALLOUT.  Hubby is flying to California for work for a week and when he comes home, he'll have a new woman in the house.  :) Headache:  I didn't have one with chemo #1, but have with #2. Heartburn:  Ditto above... been taking mylanta and Pepcid today. Mizzy!  It's so nice to hear from those who have gone before us to let us know that yes, Virginia, there is a Santa after all of this!!!  THANKS, and God Bless you!

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2007 02:21AM TexasKaren wrote: Trisha:  I echo above.  Each case is very individual.  No matter what cancer you have, even when they say "they got it all", there are microscopic cells that get out and float in your body...looking to eventually land somewhere and grow again.  It's scary, but it's true.  Adjunctive chemo (a short course, 8-12 weeks) is the best way to 'zap' those cancer cells that may be out there in the rest of your body to improve your long term chances of survival.   You are young and strong and otherwise healthy.  If it improves your chances of being around to see your kids marry and see your grandchildren, then it's worth every minute of the 'flu' for those 8-12 weeks.  We all gripe and moan and groan (that's why we love this board...we have a place to go to do that where others understand!) but all of us want to be 20++ year survivors!   Talk with your oncologist, and if you want, get a second opinion from another...doesn't hurt.  And YES, breast self exam is a life saver!!!  Make sure you tell ALL your friends and family to do theirs religiously.  That's how I found mine too. Cheryl:  Hang in there... tomorrow will be better!!  I'm in my 'good days' right now, but dose #3 looms over me on Monday. Sigh... here we go again!  I'm resolved now to feeling like crap for 5-7 days every other week.  I hope your fever goes away!  I know what you mean about the 'laying around when you have so much to do'.  I am self-employed from my home for a state medical association, and I am so far behind and I feel so guilty for being so neglectful of my duties; but my bosses all are so understanding and supportive, and they say, "Hey, it'll be over soon and you'll be back to your normal OCD self and all caught up!  We're not worried!" I just have the most amazing respect to those of you who still have children at home!  You are my heroes....I don't know how I would manage still having kids at home and running them around, school stuff, feeding them, etc.  I only have myself to worry about (my DH is self-sufficient, thank the Lord, and my 31 y/o son next door is too!)
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2007 12:00PM TexasKaren wrote: I've had fun catching up on the postings! My DH came home last night; we've been 'catching up' <wicked grin>.  He came home to the bald martian; he think's it's cute, and he's been kissing my head and neck all over.  LOL  Karen R, my hat off to you for injecting yourself.  I don't think I could ever do that; I have needle phobia so bad! Cheryl:  Get a big bottle of Mylanta Orange Creme flavor.  I've been living on it this cycle.  I have all sorts of digestive issues I didn't have with the first treatment.  I try to eat very bland, but everything seems to cause discomfort and heartburn/indigestion.  I am belching and farting like the University of Texas Longhorn football team in the locker room.  I carry chewable Pepto Bismol in my purse for emergencies too.  The chemo diet I have said "NO DAIRY" for awhile, except yougurt with active cultures and buttermilk and sour cream.  No milk (soy milk is ok).  I had a bowl of cereal the other day with 2% milk and spent the rest of the morning on the potty.  Maybe chemo does cause some temporary lactose intolerance. On flu shot; my oncologist said "no".  He said that opinions are very split on it, but he's on the side of 'no added stuff in your body while on treatment'. Hotmedic: You poor thing!  Are you getting any bone marrow boosters?  I hope you feel better quick with the transfusion.  Are you getting steriods too?  As a nurse, you know that the mood changes and lack of focus/concentration, jumping out of your skin can be s/e of those.  I get it real bad the first week after my treatment.  I make it a point to take a walk, slow and steady, around our block (2.7 miles...some block!), counting to 100 and then singing a song, and back and forth, except on my neulasta days when I'm a couch potatoe and don't care.  The exercise is good for the seratonin levels (and the constipation too!), the concentration on counting helps me focus, and the songs, well, I have to learn them for our band.  LOL   Seriously, try some mild exercise, even if you have to buy a DVD or VHS.  I know I'm blessed to live in Texas... today the temp was 86.  Gotta love it.  (Ooops, sorry you cold northern people dealing with winter coming on!) MsFris: Welcome!  I'm going to stop griping about all my trips to Abilene now (45 mins)... and again, my hat off to those of you with children at home going through this!!  I agree with Lori G:  Just reading all the posts gives me laughter, a boost, companionship, blessings, hints of what to do for my s/e, and mostly gives me a reason to stop thinking just of myself and dwelling on my problems and concentrate on those who are having more difficulty, which makes my prayer list very long every night  (a good thing when you can't go to sleep!)  Treatment #3 Monday.  I've got chemo brain; I know a couple of others are going Monday too, but can't remember who.  I'm going to have to start a notebook!

Linda and the other Tuesday ladies:  Thinking of you too. ULLA:  Where are you honey?  Hope all is well... Tonight I am saying prayers for:   All the living warriors here on bc.org and all the warriors that have gone before us, for Evy and baby, and for all the other kind of warriors that are keeping us safe and defending democracy and America.  Happy Veterans Day and hugs to all the Oct girls!

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2007 08:04AM TexasKaren wrote: Wow... I take a few days off to be a couch potato and you all just keep on going and going... Energizer Bunnies!!! Sorry for the s/e's bothering some of you (fever, infections, port problems, etc.)!!!  The prayers and positive thoughts keep going up for all. I was very tired this round... I must have slept 18 hours a day.  Finally, Sat. morning I felt like a real person again, which is good because the band played last night.  The taste issue/smell issue is driving me nuts.  Nothing tastes good or smells good and food is almost unthinkable.  That diet I posted doesn't do any good if you can't tolerate any food at all.  I've been living on baked potatoes, scrambled eggs, vanilla pudding and yogurt.   I didn't say the diet worked, just that it was given to me!   Hats off to you ladies eating salads!  I MISS THEM!! But I can't even tolerate thinking of them now. I have incredible indigestion no matter what I eat or drink.  I'm only hoping it clears a little by Turkey Day! About the trouble breathing/heart racing... I get that too, and I'm not sure what it's from, the neulasta, the chemo, the steroids, or all of it!  I just sort of all a sudden need to sit down and rest, like I hit a wall suddenly. I went "nekked" at the club with the band last night... no wig (it was so hot in there anyway), I just put a couple of temporary tattoos on my head, it was fun and got a lot of laughs, especially from some of the 'biker' guys who shave their heads too.  Chins up ladies!!  Another week is starting, and we'll get through it just like last week!
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2007 11:43AM TexasKaren wrote: haha... Karyll, you crack me up all the time.  You go girl. Last A/C treatment yesterday, and LAST neulasta shot today !!!!  HOORAY.  I feel like I've graduated...or almost (after the next couple days on the couch).  Next on to Taxotere.  Thanks, Kara, for saying it's not too bad.  I've heard it's not like A/C. Karyll, tell me what happens with you as you will be starting before me. Ulla:  Good for you.  I have found having the "BIG C" has been very liberating.  After facing your own mortality, and knowing that you will beat it or beat at it with all you have, then you find that you don't really care what people who don't know you or don't have a clue about you think.  They don't matter.   I was in Cracker Barrel over our Thanksgiving trip, and there sat another lady with just a bit of 'new fuzz' coming in (post chemo).  I took off my hat, baring all, saluted her, and we both said "God Bless", and had a big smile from everyone sitting around us.  I have not had any 'shocked' or uncomfortable reaction from anyone, because I always look them in the eye with a huge smile and a laugh.  Who can respond negatively to that? Cheryl, so sorry about your aunt.  My mother had lung cancer and they didn't do chemo either, but she was so debilitated and had so many metastesis that the chemo would have killed her before the lung cancer.  We all agreed it was for the best not to treat it.  And, I'll be with you and the chicken soup/applesauce for the next few days... that and baked potatoes are all I can tolerate for about a week.  Belated Birthday wishes Debbiel!!  Kristina:  Bless your soul!!  If there was a S/E Queen, you get my vote!  But, once again, you will come through, and they can't get your spirit!!  My eyes have been very gummy/runny too, and although I have some left, it's a trick to put on mascara each day...feel like I'm painting each lash one by one by one.. LOL  I've been told to be careful of eye makeup; make sure you are using new mascara/shadow.  Because you have lost some of your eye's protection (the lashes) the bacteria from old mascara/etc can move in. I'll be on the couch next couple of days... neulasta and this darned cold.  It's not bad, but you know how the congestion/cough, etc, makes you feel ... on top of the chemo.   UGH. HUGS to all the rest of you, I love your postings and even when I'm not up to responding, I read them all diligently and with the warmest of feelings!!  It's amazing how much I feel for all of you and we're still almost strangers, just getting to know each other....!!!

LOL!!  I have finally lost about 10 pounds.  I was actually hoping for a 20 lb 'diet' during this, but the steriods keep you all bloated!  I'm hoping by next week maybe this will all end.  I can't imagine a world without food!  (LOL) Cheryl:  Glad you are feeling better.  If you get your next round on 12/13, you should be feeling pretty good for Christmas, right? Posts.Content: Dec 5, 2007 10:09PM TexasKaren wrote: I wrote a big note here around noon today, typed and typed, and then their server went down for maintenance....sheesh!  Don't ya love technology!!! Ulla:   go to www.amazon.com   They ship to Sweden.  They have an excellent selection of books, audio cd's and audio tapes on relaxation/meditation and surviving cancer.  Hang in there honey...your body is undergoing a huge battle right now.  Someday you'll look back on it and it will be like a bad dream. Hotmedic:  I too have finished my A/C and on to Taxotere.  I'm still tired, no energy, and I expect it will stay like that until all the chemo is done and out of my body.  All the side effects of all these drugs say 'fatigue'.  And the stomach stuff too.  My onc nurse said this toxic stuff stays around in the digestive system in some people for a long while before you get back to normal.  I've bought stock in Campbell's chicken noodle soup, chiquita bananas and applesauce....!  Just listen to your tummy and your body and eat what pleases you.  Worry about "nutrition" later (I've been totally turned off by meat/protein for weeks).  By the way, those "Boost" shakes or any of the protein shakes are pretty good too.  I can't drink them cold, though, they lie like a stone in my tummy.  Kara:  I loved your card.... you have all of us beat at getting out the Christmas cheer!   I haven't even decorated the house yet.  I'm tempted not to (too tired!) but then, it's such a mood booster when you get into the spirit.  This is my son's first Christmas at home in 12 years (long story, but he screwed up royally when he was 18 and went to prison for 12 years) and I know I want to make it nice for him.  I'll get off my butt this weekend and get it done!!! Today was Evy's surgery?? or was it Tues?  Anyway, she's been in my prayers every single day, as all of you.  I hope she can let us know how she's doing soon!

Posts.Content: Dec 6, 2007 11:12PM TexasKaren wrote: Cheryl: I'm not a scarf person, but the other day I found this big multicolored one that was my mothers and I didn't feel like wearing that itchy, hot wig, so I put it on like you usually do, but took the ends and twirled them and wrapped them around back up to the top and front then tied a knot off center (kind of over one ear) and left the ends dangling... looked like a really cool gypsy!  My DH loved it, and I got lots of compliments too.  So, maybe I will be a scarf person!!    Also, for a big formal event (like a christmas party), go to the fabric store and buy a 1/8 yard of some glittzy material (sequined, etc, gold lame) and make a little 'cap' of it and wrap it up with a contrasting black velvet headband.  Cool look!  Of course, big hoop earrings too!!

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2007 06:21PM TexasKaren wrote: Wow... what a busy time!  A week until Christmas and I've not got a lot done!  But, I've been reading all the postings, and seems like most of us are doing pretty well.  THANKFULLY!   I pray we all have a wonderful, blessing filled Christmas Linda: Yes, my eyes water a lot, gummy, etc.  I have to reapply mascara a couple times a day...LOL   The Cuban dinner sounds wonderful!  What a neat idea to do something different every year!  I always just have to choose between turkey or ham...or both. The benefit went off well, even though we didn't have the crowd we wanted, we still raised about $1,000.  Not bad.  You can see pictures of this crazy 55 year old bald 'rock star' and all my wonderful musician friends who supported this effort at: http://good-times.webshots.com/album/561814676XIyKYW?vhost=good-times It wiped me out pretty good for Sunday, and then 2nd Taxotere yesterday.  Other than being a little anemic (I'm eating beets and liver and taking iron pills again) and tired and having restless leg syndrome from the steriods, I feel pretty good.  Hope this continues and no s/e's accumulate as I go on.  Found out I have to go to Cabo San Lucas, Mexico for a meeting in February.... hope I can stay good enough to make it; I need new scenery besides the chemo room every week!!! Does anyone else have the leg symptoms I get from the steroids??  achy, itchy, crampy, crawley, weird feelings for about 3 days... then goes away? I've received several of your christmas cards!!  Wonderful !!!  I wrote mine out during chemo yesterday, so when you get them, if the writing is bad and there are some crossouts of words, it was the steriods and benedryl....!!!! RE:  Preventing Lymphadema.... has anyone out there heard of the LEBED method?  They offer it here at our Oncology Center.  It is an excercise class targeting women who have had breast surgery/lymph gland removal.  It involves a lot of yoga type stretching exercises, and those who attend the class swear by it.  They meet twice a week, and use feather boas and other cute aids.   I have enough trouble getting over there once a week for chemo, so I don't go, but I'd love to.   Here is some of the info: The Lebed Method Focus on Healing through Movement and Dance is a therapeutic exercise and movement program for women who have had any type of breast cancer intervention. It has also proven helpful to people with any type of chronic illness, such as arthritis, M.S. or fibromyalgia. The Lebed Method is fun, easy to do and helps participants to: Check with your cancer services and see if there is a chapter in your area! Hope those of you in the blizzard area are ok.  Talked to a friend in Kansas who was without power for 6 days.  UGH!!! HUGS for now.... Praying for everyone !!!  Where is ULLA?????

Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2007 10:04AM TexasKaren wrote: I take Echinacea, Zinc and 1,000 mg Vit C every day during cold/flu season.  Airborne also contains these same things, as well as lots of other herbs and vitamins.   I was not taking all my usual homeopathic herbs and vitamins while I was on the 'red devil', and I didn't take it during Thanksgiving when my granddaughter gave me her cold.... :(    I should have kept my usual regimen up!!  Since I'm off the 'red devil', I've started back on all my vitamins and stuff and I'm feeling better.  A good Vitamin B complex also helps the mood swings and don't forget to keep taking your Calcium.... chemo is hard on your bones too. What is crystal rock deoderant and where can you get it???  There are some scientific reports out there that say that the aluminum chloride in our deoderants may be a cause of breast cancer!!  I've only been using baby powder lately, but believe me, that won't cut it in Texas during the summer heat ! ! !

HEART AND SOUL You have stolen a precious part of me Yet you'll never claim the heart of me. You can't touch the flame that burns in me... The spirit that lives for eternity. And a hunger in me That won't be denied I tell you boldly That you have met your match I will not give in And I will not give up. Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2008 02:40AM TexasKaren wrote: Waves:  Don't be afraid to ask for some help (medications) if you feel depressed!  In our cancer support group we laugh because nearly everyone is on something!  Zoloft, Paxil, etc.   We all have periods of ups and downs, and our downs are "really downers".  The steroids mess with us too, adding to the problem.  I had the tearies all day yesterday. I miss my mom so bad (I know some of you have posted recently that they are well-meaning but hard to deal with....Please, have them call me one day when you can't deal with them, and I'll let them mother all over me!!)  I even cried holding my puppy because she's the only thing that's here with me all day, everyday, and she loves me so much without asking for anything (except dog treats...).   The blues stink..... if there is help with medication, get it.   They, like chemo, aren't forever. Karyll, Deb, Ulla, Waves, Theresa, all my sisters:  Hope you feel better today and have more "mojo"!  A little private secret my DH doesn't even know about: when I get down like yesterday, I play an old recording of "Don't Worry, Be Happy", and I make myself sing it over and over again and I make myself get up and dance a silly dance too.  Stupid??  yes... but you know what?  It kind of works..... and now you have a picture of this crazy broad in her private moments of desperation.  A good cry now and then doesn't hurt either!

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2008 02:16PM TexasKaren wrote: I had my Taxotere #6 today!   Only 6 more to go then I'm done!  There IS a light at the end of the tunnel!!! Coach/Play/Win:  My Onc says we'll wait till both chemo and radiation is over (probably June) and then give me a month to cool off (let the glow in the dark stop ) and then do scans again.  Current recommendations are for ALL cancer patients to be scanned/tested every 6 months for the first 5 years.  For your neuropathy, are you taking Magnesium and Vit B6 and B12?  Ask your doc if you're not... they are very effective.  My neuro symptoms have abated 80% since starting them. My hair is doing the fuzzy duck thing in the back too.  A lot thicker than on top/sides.  I think we all need to take pictures of our fuzzies and post them (when they get long enough to show up on the pictures!)  Sigh, I think mine will be grey/white and straight... just like before!   Kara: I want to see the pic of you and your brother! Karyll:  Glad you aren't working too!  I believe that all things happen for a purpose.  Get your rest and just think how soon it will be over, and you'll be on the road to being 'normal' again soon.  You've been a trooper and an inspiration to all your sisters here! Waves:   Good to go on the Lexapro!  You'll feel the difference!! Steriods and benadryl are battling but I think the benadryl is winning... off to beddie!  I swear I won't ever take steriods again after this..... I've had more long-lasting s/e's from them than from the chemo almost!
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2008 02:43AM TexasKaren wrote: Girls: I'm sorry... I was mistaken about the followup scans every 6 months.... other than at your doctors discretion, they are not recommended unless you prove symptomatic during your check ups and physicals, which should be done every 3 months for the first 2-3 years, then every 6 months.  This makes sense as all these tests (MRI, pet scans, CT scans, xrays) have their own risks (even causing cancer) over time.  But the followup complete physical exams and mammograms are very important....don't miss them. The current recommendations from the American Society of Clinical Oncologists (which I hope your oncologist is a member of) for followup of breast cancer patients can be found at: http://jco.ascopubs.org/cgi/content/full/24/31/5091 It's kind of some scientific talk, but you'll understand what they are saying.

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2008 02:23AM TexasKaren wrote: Kristina:  Ok.... I'll get the sleeve next week when I see my doc again.   I've seen them, and they're not bad.... I don't mind wearing one; just wasn't sure on the mixed messages I was getting.  I'd certainly rather be safe than sorry! ! !  I'm a ditz, but not stupid!  YEA to Karen R!   Good reports are the best thing in the world! Re: Lumpectomy vs. mastectomy.  It is a very individual choice, and has to do with your diagnosis and family history, etc.  I have no breast cancer in my family, I had a very small lump (too bad it was in my lymph glands that far, but...) and the receptors, etc, were negative.  So, the trauma/healing time of a mastectomy wasn't really a logical choice.  Lumpectomy was the best solution.  However, I did consider it for a moment; it would be nice to believe that if we cut those things off the cancer would never return.  That's not cut and dried either; the cancer cells are already floating around in our bodies (that's why we do chemo and radiation) and they can land and grow anywhere.  I believe more in having faith that God and medicine are curing me and I won't battle this ever again, and I also believe that it's important to NOT LIVE IN FEAR of it returning.  Fear robs you of your life and your spirit, and even though I will be diligent and watchful in the future, I refuse to let this rule my life from now on. To those of you who are facing reconstruction and new boobs, I applaud you for enduring yet more surgeries and healing and I am there with you in prayer and thoughts as you continue this journey of wholeness.  That's what it's about, becoming whole again in whatever manner we chose for our individual selves.  We each know what our own "personal wholeness" must be. Where is our Karyll!?  Praying for her...

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2008 05:33AM TexasKaren wrote: Karen.... send that cool stuff down here!  It's 100 again today.  I want to be out in the yard doing stuff, but I can't... too darned hot!! People come in and out of your lives for many reasons.  You never know what little thing you do or say will have a major impact.  We always think of  only "influencing" people we are around a lot, like our families and close friends.  You never know when a total stranger will be affected by something small, or, who will affect you.   Little story here:  When I was finishing chemo, I heard one of our popular radio DJ's (a gal, Tiffany) on the local Classic Rock station (Hello! I'm going to listen to anything else when I play in a rock and roll band?? ha)  She was saying how she had a big scare that week, found something and had to go have a biopsy, was sweating it for four days, all the anxiety, etc, her mom crying, and waiting for the reports.  She wasn't asking for any pity or attention, she just wanted her listeners to know why she wasn't her usual crazy self on the air (she's a real hoot!)  I casually emailed her a little note about staying positive, realizing that most biopsies are negative and a little about my journey, etc.  I honestly don't remember exactly WHAT I wrote her, I just wanted her to know that someone cared and was praying for her.  The next day, she reported that the scare was over and everything was alright.  Now, jump ahead a couple more months.  This DJ is one of our band's strongest supporters.  She will talk about us on the air, tell people to come see us, talk about where and when we're playing, etc, and she comes to all our shows.  She doesn't do that for any other band.  All this time, I thought she really loved our band (she does, by the way..ha) but last night she told everyone that it was because of me and my little email...she said she'd never been so touched by a total stranger and that she would be in our corner forever.    I was awestruck, and the power of one simple little action was brought home.   This revelation came at a very important time for me.  I lost a very special friend (my son's fiance) who was killed in a car wreck on Friday morning.  We are in terrible grief here; my poor son lost a very special woman, and I lost a very special friend.  She was an amazing woman who gave and gave and gave and took no s**t from anyone.  She was 4'10" of grit and grace, she's been a prison guard for 18 years, had 3 children of her own and adopted 3 others, and was an inspiration to everyone who knew her.  Today, instead of grieving deeply, I am committed to taking a few choice 'actions' that she gave to me, and continuing to pass them forward to others I may come across... she would like that very much. Thanks to all of you who have given me so much too...!   I want to see pictures of the new redheads... :))

Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2007 11:53PM TexasKaren wrote: Hi!  I am finding all this information SO INVALUABLE!!  I am Karen (I've seen several Karen's in here!) from Sweetwater, Texas.  I start my chemo next week; getting my port put in tomorrow.  Chemo will be A/C for 4 cycles (every two weeks) and then T/C for 4 cycles weekly.  Radiation will follow early next year. I found a large lump in my armpit in late July.... mammo and breast u/s were very inconclusive; very small area found in left breast.  I opted for open biopsy because the area was so small and I still wanted that large lymph out to see what it was (could have been several things, including lymphoma).  I was prepared for lumpectomy and node removal if they found something, and they did, but very small (1.5 cm).  Bad news... 8 of 14 lymphs were involved.  So, it is a little agressive booger.  The good news is that after all the scans and tests, no mets were found anywhere.  We caught it early My husband and I play in a classic Rock & Roll band....(www.myspace.com/thescreamingmoondogs) and we are already planning some fun stuff for when I go bald.  We are working with the Oncology center here to have a big fund raiser in November to get money for women who can not afford mammograms.  I am not afraid of losing my hair, I'm just sad: I just spent the last year growing my hair out to shoulder length!!!  Oh well, start over again.  It's just hair.   I am planning on getting my chemo on Mondays so that maybe I'll not be so zapped by the weekend when we play??  Any ideas for help there?  Should I take supplements or anything? I have added all of you to my prayer list.... and I am so blessed to be among such a strong and caring sisterhood!

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2010 04:46PM TexasKaren wrote: Thanks Everyone !!!   Everyone on BC.ORG is wonderful.  My "primary" group is the October 2007 Chemo Girls.  We all were diagnosed around the same time and started chemo together then.  Several of us are constantly in touch, and life long friends now, and they continue to support me with this new problem.  I am the first of that group to have recurrence.  I pray daily that I am the ONLY one. I am doing relatively fine.  I have strong faith and a totally awesome husband, and we march on the same path together, hand in hand.  I knew that I had an agressive cancer that could come back, and I've been more or less prepared since the beginning.  I am not afraid of the future, and I don't fear the beast... I am only out to help as many as I can also along this journey, and to help the cause to find a cure.  We are so fortunate to be living now; the treatments and the outcomes were so much worse even 10 years ago, and someday... soon, we all pray... they WILL find a cure.  In the meantime, we all take each day believing we have been blessed, and loving the life that we have. I get more MRI's and my port in next week right after Christmas... a new type of "power port"... (still haven't figured out where the batteries go...) and then I'll start the new duo first week of January.   I'll check in here, and believe me, I'll be listening to your advice and asking questions!  I wish all of you, and your loved ones, a very blessed and Merry Christmas/Holiday Season (see, I'm politically correct!)... Texas Karen

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2011 10:24AM TexasKaren wrote: I have degenerative disc disease in my neck.  It presented the same way, and I was terrified it was mets too, as I was just dx'd with recurrence to bones in lower spine and shoulder.  But, it's just nerve compression.   They need to do a MRI on her neck to see if there is compression or even a collapsed disc, but massage therapy should help.  It will come and go, mine is fine for awhile, and then I'll sleep crooked or something and it will act up for several days, numbness, tingling, shooting pain down my arm.  The neck itself never hurts! Chemo brain IS REAL.  And with hormonal changes, could be worse, not to mention dealing with anxiety and depression of having cancer.  There are medications that can help if she is struggling with depression or anxiety. It IS possible to get more mets while in treatment if the treatment isn't working.  I was on Xeloda and Gemzar and Navelbine, and my disease progressed, but only in my bones where the initial recurrence was, because they just weren't effective.  If she's is on first chemo (recent dx and first treatment) it is highly unlikely that she will develop mets this close to diagnosis, if her primary scans were clear.   Fear is our worst enemy in this disease... we fear that every ache and pain is "more cancer".  Even after treatment stops, whenever we have our repeat scans, we are fearful of what might turn up.  Living in fear is not living at all.  Living with hope and courage and faith will bring much more peace of mind, and will also affect your body.  We are what we think...if you think you have more cancer, chances are down the line you will.  BE POSITIVE.   Your friend will be ok.

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2007 02:35AM TexasKaren wrote: Kara:  Hoping you have a great weekend like me before we get #3 on Monday!  Our Hem/Onc center is kind of wide open with TV's everywhere, probably seats 30, not much privacy, but so far there's not been any noise or distractions.  The pedi-onc patients are the cute ones.  They come in a group and get chemo on the same day; they have crafts for them to do (like you're going to make an 8 y/o sit for 2 hours while his drip finishes!) and they walk around with their IV poles and march and sing.  They are so adaptable, naive about their conditions (one with leukemia and in treatment for the last 6 months finally realized he has "CANCER" a couple of weeks ago, and promptly went around telling everyone like he just got a new puppy!), and they are so empathic with even the adult patients, giving them hugs when they see that they are down.  I almost changed my chemo day to Thursday to be with them, but I have to feel better by the weekend for the band. We can bring snacks if we want, but they tell everyone not to make them 'smelly'... LOL   I'm going to take sugar cookies on Monday.  They also have drinks and lots of WATER!  What's nice (of course, it's Texas!) is that there is a beautiful little outside private garden/meditation area with tables and chairs and a fountain... you can go out there too with your IV pole! Karyll:  That's funny about the vinegar!  I'm having trouble with coffee, which I used to ADORE and consume in mass quantities.... it all smells like diesel and tastes terrible, no matter what kind I try.  I've been saying I was going to cut down on coffee for years; I guess my health angel is making it happen despite my addiction to it! Ladies:  Found a great website for hats/caps/etc!  Good prices and lots of choices. http://www.headcovers.com/

Posts.Content: Dec 24, 2007 12:25PM TexasKaren wrote: NFlood!  Welcome!  I was raised not far from Parker, CO and miss my mountains!   Don't worry about weight gain.... your body will tell you what it needs.  Right now, just get through the Chemo....you can diet and exercise afterwards.  Most of us haven't gained a lot and what we've gained is because of the steroids and fluid retention (and don't forget the constipation!).  I jump back and forth between 164 and 174... depending on what day of the treatment it is!!  I was concerned until I saw the pattern developing... and it hasn't changed... I just yo-yo back and forth.  I had to stop walking my 2.5 miles a day and that has been the worst of it.  BUT, I know that when I finish chemo I'll get back to "normal" pretty fast!  The nutritionist will help you too.   Don't fear the hair loss... I think most of us will tell you that although we dreaded it greatly, it has actually been rather 'liberating' in a way.  It's kind of nice realizing that we aren't just our exteriors.... we can be judged for our spirit, heart and our intelligence just as well as what kind of 'hairdo' we are wearing, and actually people are very kind and not weirded out by us baldies!  Karyll:  I am so sorry to hear your news.  Part of me wants to be vindictive and angry, but a deeper part of me tells me that you will find something a whole lot better through this trial.  Some employer is going to get a wonderful person in the near future for their company.... YOU!  And, I have a gut feeling that the work that you will find will be better than that other job and more satisfying to you in the long run.  Don't be afraid to chase some old dreams lying dormant in you... go for the gold ring when you go looking for a new job, and in the meantime, your situation is in my prayers!! Cheryl.... you are a brave soul for putting that doll house together!!!  YIKES.  But I know she'll love it. Cheryl, Kara, Karen R, Lori, Ulla, Evy and Deb and ALL:   Peace and Love to all of my sisters this week and have a blessed Christmas with your loved ones!!!

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2007 01:58PM TexasKaren wrote: ULLA:  You aren't simply beautiful... YOU ARE GORGEOUS, MARVELOUS, and remember... this will end in a few weeks.  Sadly, with the loss of your baby, you haven't gone through pregnancy, but believe me, every one of us who have had children felt so totally FAT, UGLY and UNFEMININE towards the end.  And you know what?  It went away....  just like this chemo nightmare will.  You have to keep your heart and your head focused on the FUTURE, not just today.  The weight, the puffiness, all of it will go away... and, I bet you, like most of us, are harder on yourself than anyone.  Your sisters bet you a trip to the US (hahaha) that you don't look half as bad as you think you do!!! Linda:  I had tears too for your "graduation" ceremony!  How wonderful for you and how special they are at your center!!! Taxotere #3 today, so I'm buzzin' on the steroids!!  Yes, I have some neuropathy starting in fingers and toes; doc said it usually doesn't start this soon, so he cut my dose by 20%, and put me on Vit B6 and Magnesium....both help nerve function.  I told him I had an Onc doc friend at MD Anderson who treats with Vit B 12 injections, so he threw that in too... said "it' can't hurt!".  LOL  Love the man.   Nicki and Hotmedic:  If you are on Taxol/Taxotere, tell your docs about the fingers/hands.... jump on it quick.  My doc says, "MOST of the time the neuropathy will go away after awhile (we're talking months here after chemo...) BUT, sometimes it can be permanent"...so, get them on it fast.   I'm having it in my fingers and toes and I've only had 2 treatments.  I have lots of family with diabetic neuropathy so I know the symptoms.  Hands/fingers feel 'funny', like kind of waxy coated, but at the same time tingly and hyper-sensitive.  It can progress to not being able to hold things or feel things you are touching (very late stage). The kicker is that all the steriods they pump you with can cause some numbness/tingly feeling in the hands too... so don't panic, but the steriod induced tinglyness goes away in a couple of days.  I get it in my legs for 2-3 days after steroids and it makes me feel like I have 'restless leg syndrome". GOSH!!!   Sorry, it's those steroids, girls!!!  Didn't mean to write a dissertation here !!!!    One final funny note on my steroid rush:  Went to get my passport photo taken (you know, my work is MAKING me go to Cabo San Lucas in Feb), but the lady didn't know what to do with me... Bald vs Wig.  So she told me I have to call the Wash DC office to find out if I can wear my wig for the photograph.  If not, my passport photo will have this scary looking BALD lady's picture on it for the NEXT 10 YEARS!!!!

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2007 11:46AM TexasKaren wrote: I can see that everyone is really busy at the end of the year!!!  Hope all are feeling good.   Here's my New Year's wish for all of you: My Wish for You in 2008: May peace break into your house and may thieves come to steal your debts. May the pockets of your jeans become a magnet for $100 bills. May love stick to your face like Vaseline and may laughter assault your lips! May your clothes smell of success like smoking tires and may happiness slap you across the face. May your tears be only those of joy. May the problems you have forget your home address. In simple words, my sisters, may 2008 be the best year of your life!!! Here's a few quotes to help keep your mind 'above' your condition 'below': Challenges are what make life interesting; overcoming them is what makes life meaningful.        -Joshua J. Marine Difficulties are meant to rouse, not discourage. The human spirit is made to grow strong by conflict.       -William Ellery Channing It is not good for all our wishes to be filled; through sickness we recognize the value of health; through evil, the value of good; through hunger, the value of food; through exertion, the value of rest.       - Greek Proverb   Talk to you next year!

I know they have ways of avoiding heart damage, but it's scary anyway.  They have one of the brand new radiation machines now and I hope it is like they say and 'far superior' to the old machine. Cheryl:  Great pics!  And I can't believe you wrapped that house up!!  I know she's so proud of it. Ulla:  Don't be afraid to get some help... a good psychologist/grief counselor could help you a lot in dealing with all you are going through.  Medications can help, but talking things through with someone is important!  Your isolation there only compounds your many issues.  We're here for you, but you need someone close there that you can rely on too! Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2008 03:14PM TexasKaren wrote: Theresa!  Welcome!  Hate that you are here; but, again, glad you found us and we found you too!  I LOVE your website!  Thanks for sharing!  Don't get psyched about the chemo side effects; as a nurse you know that we're all different, some have had bad s/e's; some have had none.  Take it a day at a time, a treatment at a time.  Prayer helps, and you have been added to my list! Terry:  Yes, get walking!  It will help your stamina and energy.  Keep it up for as long as you can.  I had to stop after my second A/C treatment (just felt too drained!), but now that I'm on Taxotere, I'm back to step aerobics and pilates class again!  I'm feeling my "MOJO" come back. Linda!  Thanks for the heads up on coloring hair too fast... my hubby's been asking when he can have his "redhead" back.  I'll just have to tell him to be patient! Ulla!  Hope you feel better soon... I know you feel better on the steriods, but believe me (I have an aunt with Lupus) you would NOT want to be on steriods for long term!  Many worse side effects!  Ladies:  I just had the best informative meeting with our women's cancer group tonight.  A gentleman from our area who was dx'd with non-hodgkins lymphoma throughout his body (over 40 egg sized tumors) a year ago and who is totally in remission today.  His personal faith message was wonderful, but his focus is on nutrition to keep cancer from coming back.   I will provide some of his  information in future messages, but did you know that cancer feeds on sugar?  I did; they even give you a big dose of sugar before your PET scans because it 'highlights' tumors growing. (message here, stop eating anything with processed sugar, switch to Stevia/honey/raw sugar in small amounts)  Also, cancer hates oxygen... the better you breathe (big deep breaths in and out, pushing that ol oxygen throughout your body) the worse cancer likes it!   There are some cancer treatment centers that are currently doing trials on oxygenation chambers where patients with metastesis sit and breath enriched oxygen air a couple of times a week....results are looking promising. Amazingly, I believe that God was speaking to me about my diet even before my cancer diagnosis.  This past summer I starting studying and reading about alkalyzing/Ph diets and I attempted to switch a lot of our diet to healthier eating (we only have red meat once a week, two meatless dinners a week, lots more veggies and fruit, etc); now I am hearing daily more and more about the subject of nutrition and health.  Even Montel Williams has reduced his MS symptoms through his new diet (new book out) Go figure.....I'm 55... hope it's not too late to teach an old dog new tricks! Brochitis is getting better with antibiotics... I agree... sick and tired of being sick and tired!
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2008 01:53PM TexasKaren wrote: AH HA!  I think our moods are improving!  Lots of jokes here today! MeandPC(Lisa): WELCOME !!  Everyone is welcome here.  Oct, Nov, Dec... who counts?  We're all in this together!  Hair growing?  Well, everyone is different.  I hope yours continues to grow.  Mine was stubbly for awhile too, but the last couple of weeks is coming on.  My eyelashes keep getting thinner though  (big boohoo!)  I'm down to about 7 on the bottom right eye.  LOL  Yes, that is me in the pic... I need to put a new one up, the benefit we did where I let everyone sign my head/neck/shoulders was in December.  It was fun! The sugar thing is TOUGH.... But, if you can cut back as much as possible, that's the key.  Cancer feeds on sugar; therefore, the less sugar you eat, the less food the cancer has.  I do enjoy my hot cocoa... I just buy the sugar free one.  I am using the Stevia a lot now; I'm getting used to it.  And most of my 'sweet' comes from fruits and a little bit of honey.  When I get a real craving, I get a teaspoon of p-nut butter and honey and slowly lick it... MMMM.  The nutrition guy and several others told me that as you 'get off the sugar' wagon, it gets easier; your body adjusts and doesn't crave the sweets anymore.  I find that easy to believe, because my M-in-law is diabetic, and after a couple of years of 'no more sweets', she never wanted any anymore and just doesn't have any cravings! Lori:  glad to hear from you, and that your sister is doing good!  Prayers work, I swear by them!  How is your radiation going? I went back to step aerobics tonight after missing a week because of the bronchitis, and they kicked my post-chemo butt.... I'm going to take some Aleve and go to bed.  I want my MoJo back!!

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2008 12:45PM TexasKaren wrote: Evy: Oh a PUPPY!!  I bet it's such a cute puppy!!!  I know the kids love it! It's a rock and a hard place that our country has us in as far as insurance/medical care.  Even if you find a good job with good insurance, they may still deny you because of a 'pre-existing' condition!!  It's crap.  We have the best health care in the world, and it's so full of holes and problems that need fixing!!  Talk to your cancer center about possible solutions.  Maybe there is a job at the hospital you might be interested in.  My experience has been that the medical profession 'takes care of it's own'... even if you have a 90 day or so period without insurance with them, many times they will 'comp' you some of the services if you need it. Also, the medical field is one right now that isn't suffering from layoffs and cutbacks!  I don't know what job you did before, but there are lots of jobs in the medical profession; clerical, technical, even just cooking and housekeeping services, the gift shop, etc.  Some hospitals even have tuition assistance for on the job training too like nurses aids, lvn's, or school that you can attend to become more technical, like an ultrasound tech or stuff.   Glad to hear you're doing better hon... despite the Taxol and the night pee pee breaks.. LOL  This too shall pass ! !   Get that puppy trained!

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2007 01:28PM TexasKaren wrote: Hi all!  Well, I never expected it to be like this...  My first A/C "cocktail".  Treatment was easy; you just sit in a chair and drink and watch TV, read, etc.  The staff is great.  This part of it will be easy (the actual administration of the chemo)  As far as side effects, what I didn't expect was to feel like I'm on some sort of a trip (ok, you got me, I'm a child of the 60's-70's, but I ain't namin' names).  I feel like I did some very bad psychedelics.  It's almost midnite and I'm still 'disconnected', spacey, can't focus, don't feel like doing anything, but can't sit down, I can't find the words I want to say, etc.  I had a little bit of diarrhea, but not much, and it went away.  Cooked spegetti for my guys (hubby and son) but it didn't taste good to me, so I had plain spegetti with a dab of butter and some cooked carrots.  So far, no nausea.  Just this really REALLY weird feeling.  Is it the steroids they give you?    I'm going to try to sleep, but I have a feeling I'll be like others of you and will be up and down all night. HINT THAT NO ONE ELSE HAS SAID:   Probably because of all the fluids I drank the last two days getting 'hydrated' and the steroids, my fingers started getting puffy (I usually take a water pill daily, but didn't until I cleared it with the doc).  I almost didn't get my rings off in time.  I would have hated to cut my wedding band!   Just a heads up for those of you starting chemo..... leave the rings off for awhile!! Get the neulasta tomorrow... I'm going to premedicate with Aleve before I go....  hope this feeling is better or I'll have to have my son drive me!

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2012 09:18PM TexasKaren wrote: Brenda is right on !!  We all face these issues, and we have to find the POSITIVE ways to deal with them..  living in negativity only draws negativity to you.  Whenever you feel consumed by your own self and your issues, step back, watch someone else in the chemo/cancer clinic, and notice that there are a lot more people in worse shape than you!  Go give them a hug and a reassuring, "It's going to be alright", and you'll be amazed at what happens.   I have a special 'angel' that I help on Weds.  He is 74, consumed with prostate cancer, and alzheimers... he only has a brother, who is 70, as caretaker.  I sit next to him and help watch him while I'm getting my chemo, talk to him, hold his hand, and let his brother go out for a bite to eat.  The other day, Fred even remembered my name~!  What joy!  It totally takes me out of my 'it's chemo day' funk and I leave feeling very good.  My chemo day is going to be changing, I think, and I'll be very sorry to lose Fred and Allen; but maybe I can keep Weds. on my new regimen.

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2011 03:57PM TexasKaren wrote: I'm sorry you are so down....!  We all need those times, but not at family celebrations.  Take a deep breath, and say, "I WILL be here for 17 and 18".... !!!  Put your mind on the positive side, forget the negative for today (Put those pains, etc, on the back burner of your mind and forget them for the next 12 hours) and thank God for the blessing you have, the treatment options that are available, even IF something is wrong, and the fact that hair is just hair... you can change it again tomorrow!  And give birthday boy a hug from all of us sisters here... he has a special mom!!
